De studententijd is een tijd van ontwikkeling, vriendschappen sluiten, ontdekken en kennis opdoen. Met studie en stages, bijbaantjes of buitenlandervaring, sport, studentenverenigingen of uren in de bibliotheek leggen we een basis voor de toekomst.

De ruimte die ik heb gekregen moet de huidige generatie studenten op het mbo, hbo en universiteit ook krijgen. Daarom is het belangrijk dat we de basisbeurs instellen die past bij 2022.

De beurs die het kabinet nu wil geven (thuiswonende 91 euro en uitwonende studenten 255 euro) is vergelijkbaar met de beurs die ik had in 2008. Maar inmiddels betalen studenten 30% meer huur, en 45% meer collegegeld. Volt wil daarom ten minste naar een basisbeurs van 112 euro voor thuiswonende studenten en 312 euro voor uitwonende studenten. 

Samen met @partijvddieren en @christenunie zetten we ons ook in om de financiering voor studenten met een beperking makkelijker te maken. En we proberen te voorkomen dat de snel stijgende inflatie nu al gevolgen heeft voor het collegegeld in 2023. Morgen stemmen we over de moties!

But on 7 April I had the privilege to be invited onto the nationally televised debate programme on DR called Debatten.
I was there to argue why Denmark should repeal the Defense Optout and engage fully with our European neighbours on issues of security and foreign policy.

A recent poll confirms the desire by a majority of Danes to drop the Optout and this leads to the next question:

What is our vision for Europe? 

I believe that Denmark should engage deeply in the development of our continent, sharing our best practices and help citizens.
By repealing the Optout, we can:

1) Act on regional security issues rather than waiting for NATO.
2) Make sure our combat ready troops can engage in EU missions safely and effectively. 
3) Share purchasing across Europe to enable better cooperation and scale.

Some people are also expressing concern because they don't trust the politicians, or they are afraid that this is a final decision. 

We #vote for our nationally elected officials every 4 years and we vote for our European Parliament every 5 years.

The problem is that Europe, EU and European politics are not part of the discussions in national or local elections.
But our national leaders very much engage in European politics when they join the European Council meetings where finance ministers and prime minsters of the eu27 meet to align their challenges across EU.

Our politicians just don't talk about Europe and THAT is the real problem with Danish politics. 
We don't discuss how decisions are made and this makes it difficult/impossible to fully understand the processes which again generates mistrust.

To change politics, to enable citizens to be change-makers we need clarity and transparency.

#optout #politics #television #debate #Denmark #eu #europe

#VoltersStories: in this series, Volters from across Europe will share their stories on why they joined our pan-European movement, and how this enriched their lives. The first personal story is told by Silvia Panini (@silviapaninivolt):

â€It is always difficult to explain what Volt Europa is and how it differs from other political forces â€” perhaps because it is much more than just a traditional party.

ğŸ¤ Volt is a community.
Among Volt members there are many people like me but many of them are also quite different: there are those who still study and those who have a family, those who live in Italy and those who do not, and those who make political communication and expose themselves and those who work behind the scenes. But we all share the desire to change something in the political and social system in which we live. We have a vision, a dream, an ideaâš¡ and we bring our different experiences to the community to make it real.

ğŸ“– Volt is a school.
Given the great breadth of experience the volunteers' bring in, each Volter has a lot to teach and contribute to the community.
In Volt, all the activities that are usually carried out by professionals in large parties are realised by volunteers. Since I've been here, I've learned to speak in public, deal with public relations with journalists and politicians, and report on an election campaign.
ğŸ’œ And above all, I learned to deal with different people, different realities, and different worlds; to make the people around me stronger and more aware of their abilities; to synthesize different ideas.

â­ Volt is an opportunity.
It is the opportunity to regain confidence in the politics that is made by people, for people, without screaming or giving false hope, by being fear-mongering and winning votes, but with competence and a spirit of learning.â€

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Gender equality is a fundamental right intrinsically linked to sustainable development. In the current state of our societies, womenâ€™s rights are being constantly threatened. 

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º The report issued during Panel 1 â€œStronger economy, social justice and jobs/education, culture youth and sport/digitalâ€ of the Conference of the Future of Europe is clear: 

The EU Gender Equality Strategy should be a priority; civil rights and gender equality should be achieved at the European level in all countries *without exception*. 

âŒ›ï¸ According to the World Economic Forumâ€™s Global Gender Gap Report (GGGR), only 68% of the gender gap is closed in 2022. The GGGR further estimates that gender parity will not be reached before 132 years. 

Europe has the second-highest level of gender parity currently standing at 76,6% yet important disparities can not be unseen. 

Within the EU, a difference of almost 20 percentage points between the member states is distinguishable. Measures are urgently needed to close this gender gap! 

To achieve gender equality, Volt Europa is committed to the following: 

â€¢ Make reporting on gender representation mandatory at all levels of government
â€¢ Require all mid-sized to large companies to disclose and report on gender balance and the gender pay gap. 
â€¢ Enable equal paid maternity and paternity leave

(On the EU Gender Gap Index 2022 visual, Central and Eastern Europe countries are in red, Northern Europe countries in green, Southern Europe countries in yellow and Western Europe countries in purple.)

#VoltersQuotes: â€It does not matter which party you are involved in. It's a lot of work that's not always fun. But doing nothing is even less fun." â€“ by Jochen Nibbe (@jochennibbe)

Fighting for a Europe we can live in â€“ a personal message from Conny Kawohl, Co-Lead Diversity Council at Volt Europa

Far-right forces are moving into parliamentary buildings, turning once proud democracies into autocracies. Fascist rhetoric has taken a hold on public discourse and is being perpetuated without discernment. It seems like we are just following along in their playbook.

I believe that Volt has answers to many of Europe's biggest issues. I believe that we are a strong, diverse set of pan-European voices who unite under the same idea of a united Europe with strong liberal, democratic values and an inclusive mindset.

But we need to be careful - our European ideals don't always translate well outside of our bubble. This fuzzy warm feeling that we get when we talk about Europe isn't something everyone in Europe has experienced, or will ever experience for that matter. It is one of a privileged elite. We need to recognise that there are very hard-hitting issues for people in Europe today that we still fail to adequately name. The fear of poverty and homelessness, the deep-seated anxiety around our climate emergency and the impact it has and will continue to have on our lives. Additionally, experiences of discrimination based on gender, sexuality, age, ability, faith, ethnicity or status are just shrugged off as marginal.

Let us use the energy that exists within our movement and increase our solidarity, be visible on the streets and inspire others to join us. Let's set a clear signal that we stand against fascism, and on the side of a diverse Europe of many voices and lived experiences. Let's build networks of care with organisations near and far, and listen to their experiences and best practices.

And letâ€™s become active allies and supporters - you don't need to have a disability to speak up for accessibility, and you don't need to be Jewish to support the Jewish community. Everyone can support indigenous and people of colour to finally be heard and point out white privilege and racism. You don't need to be a woman to be a feminist!

Join Volt and letâ€™s turn our frustrations and fears into a force for good: https://volt.team/join

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡ºğŸƒ EU leaders gather February 9 & 10 to discuss the Unionâ€™s migration policy. 
Volt offers a solution to the ineffective and inhumane treatment of people entering Europe. Our approach would be better for migrants and for European citizens!

Link to the full article on Medium in our story and bio! > 

What needs to be fixed?
ğŸ—ºï¸ Distribution key to 27 EU countries: Letâ€™s tackle this with all member states!
ğŸ‘·Allow them to work from day 1: Letâ€™s not waste their potential!
ğŸšªDevelop a clear vision on regular migration: To ensure safe channels!

The EUâ€™s current approach to asylum stems from the failed 1990 Dublin Regulation, which places most burden on countries of arrival. We need to revise this system to make sure all member states help with receiving migrants.

New arrivals are stopped from working, and have little contact with their host country. We should ease asylum seeker access to job markets. This carries benefits for all EU citizens, as it helps with our labour market shortages and quick integration, as we have seen with Ukrainian arrivals.

The EU should also create a clear vision on regular migration channels. Irregular migration is run by smugglers, dangerous for migrants, and makes it difficult to process new arrivals. Opening legal migration flows will unburden authorities and help keep people safe. 

Asylum seeker policy falls under EU legislation, and is something no member state can solve on their own. However, the EU has shown remarkably little progress in creating a system which shares the responsibility between member states, and which allows migrants to work and thrive in their host country.

#VoltInThePress: Volt Greece announces alliance
Jan 31st/Feb 1st - Greece - Pressenza Athens/inkefalonia/OLAFAQ

The Ecological Greens, Greens, Greens-Solidarity, Pirates, Animal Party, Volt and the ecofeminist Quinni Circle are the seven parties that form the Green and Purple alliance to change the way politics is conducted in Greece. It is an alliance that aspires to bring into programmatic agreement different ideological approaches mainly on issues concerning the economy, labour, development and the concept of public interest. The Co-Presidents of Volt Greece are Olga Dourou and Nicolaos Fournarakis, Manos Avgerinos and Katerina Georgiou are the spokespersons.
Electra Rome Dochtsi, General Secretary of Volt Greece, said "Modern problems know no borders. The climate, energy and health crises, the war in Ukraine and the rapid rise of the far right have shown us that Europe needs change more than ever before. In Volt we believe that our country can improve if we improve the whole European Union.â€
Manos said in his interview: â€œIn about a month we're going to hold our first GA in Athens, hoping to become an attractive proposal and change the way politics is done in Greece. At the same time, we have also agreed to participate in the upcoming national elections with the Green and Purple coalition and generally the project is getting very interestingâ€.

Volt stands behind the women of Iran! Three words symbolise the revolution: Women, Life, Freedom. Jin, Jiyan, Azadi. These are the words which have inspired young and old, man and woman, urban and rural - everyone, to stand up against a regime which for too many years has ruled with violent oppression.

The fight for freedom, democracy, and equality, has battles in many different countries. The people of Iran inspire us to cherish the freedoms we have in Europe, and to do whatever we can to support them in their struggle.

As the revolution in Iran falls out of our news cycles in the West, it is important to keep attention on it. Spread the word, inform yourself, and speak up for those without a voice!

On the 23rd of June, the results of The Conference on the Future of Europe will be presented. In the upcoming days, we will take a sharper look at three of the proposals discussed by participants.

Happy April 25th! 
Today, we celebrate an important day for liberty and democracy in both Italy and Portugal. In Italy, we honour Liberation Day, marking the end of the country's nazifascism occupation during World War II. In Portugal, we commemorate the anniversary of the Carnation Revolution, a peaceful coup that ended the dictatorship and paved the way for democracy.

On this day, we remember the sacrifices of thousands of people, soldiers and partisans, who fought and gave their lives for freedom and rights. We also reflect on the importance of the European ideal and democracy in securing and preserving our freedoms and values.

But today we cannot only look critically at the past, we must also look with determination at the present and the future. The fight against fascism and totalitarianism are never over. Fascist ideas are still alive and dangerous in our society, and still threaten the fundamental values of humanity. We cannot afford to be indifferent to these threats.

As we celebrate April 25th, let us come together to continue the fight for a more just and democratic Europe. Together, we can build a brighter future for all and safeguard our cherished democratic principles! Join Volt - link in bio!

#April25th #LiberationDay #CarnationRevolution #Italy #Portugal #Liberty #Democracy #JoinVoltEuropa #VoltEuropa #25Aprile

Het is zomer! Dat betekent... tijd voor een goed boek. ğŸ“šğŸ“–

Linda Bode, raadslid van @voltutrecht, deelt haar ideale vakantieboek, zodat ook jij genoeg te lezen hebt deze zomer! â˜€ï¸

Ga je de energiekosten betalen of doe je boodschappen? Steeds meer gezinnen moeten zichzelf deze vraag stellen, en 300.000 kinderen in Nederland glijden af in armoede. Gisteren kwam de Kamer terug van reces, de aanleiding was niet het gigantische koopkracht probleem, maar een minister die een partijpolitieke stunt uithaalde door tegen het regeerakkoord in te gaan.

Deze tijd vraagt om een kabinet dat zichtbaar is, perspectief biedt, en alles op alles zet om de mensen die het nodig hebben te helpen. Om het land bij elkaar te brengen, en ons voor te bereiden op een zware herfst en winter. Maar de afgelopen maanden heeft het kabinet keer op keer de nodige hulp uitgesteld. Gezegd dat er geen ruimte was, maar dat we ze kunnen vertrouwen om op Prinsjesdag met een plan te komen.

Ik hoop dat ze daad bij woord voegen, met een plan komen waar de hele Kamer achter kan staan, en waar we de mensen die nu financieel in de knel raken echt mee helpen: niet alleen voor 2023, maar al voor de komende herfst en winter, en de komende 5 jaar.

De Europese Commissie wil strengere lobbyregels in Nederland. En terecht, want dat moet beter. Volt is blij dat het kabinet werk gaat maken van de voorstellen die @laurensdassen en Groep Omtzigt hebben ingediend: 
- Een bindende gedragscode voor bewindspersonen
- Onafhankelijk adviseur voor bewindspersonen

Voltâ€™s voorstel voor een afkoelperiode van 2 jaar voor bewindslieden wordt nu ook eindelijk wettelijk vastgelegd!

Ook in de gemeente wil Volt zorgen voor een betere waarborging van politiek-bestuurlijke integriteit. Wat blijkt: er zijn geen lokale lobbyregisters! Onze Raadsleden stellen hier vragen over. Daarover stelde Niels Scholten, de fractievoorzitter van Volt Arnhem, al eerder vragen aan het Arnhemse College.

Last month, @voltnederland proposed in the Dutch parliament a policy that would ensure free meals at schools for children. Because of the soaring inflation, many families have trouble affording even basic necessities like food for three meals a day. 

Voltâ€™s proposal was supported by parliament, and adopted by the government. 100 million euros have been allocated to provide free meals for schools across The Netherlands, ensuring that every child has the energy to pay attention to school. 

Measures like this should be adopted across Europe. Everywhere people are struggling to pay the bills. Governments must protect the most vulnerable of us, and ensure that no child goes hungry this winter. By providing free meals at schools, governments can ease the burden on families, while simultaneously giving children equal access to healthy diets.

Congratulations @voltnederland & @laurens.dassen for this successful proposal!

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: This spring, our MEP @damian.boeselager, together with other MEPs, introduced a proposal on how the electoral law for the European elections could be revised. This reform includes one thing in particular, which is also a requirement of the Conference on the Future of Europe: Transnational lists ğŸ“‹

What do transnational lists mean?ğŸ§

If there were transnational lists in European elections, citizens could not only elect people from national parties to Brussels but also vote for European parties with a second vote

What would be the added value of transnational lists?ğŸ¤©

Transnational lists would take us one step further towards genuine European democracy. People could, for example, vote for a conservative Europe or a social Europe with their second vote. This would give them more options than just deciding whether to vote for or against the EU with their first vote. 

Let's try more democracy together!

#EuropeanParliament, #Transnational, #EuropeanUnion

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Renewable Energy Now â€“ We all know that the use of combustible fuels creates greenhouse gasses and that EU member states must reduce this type of energy to comply with the Paris Agreement. Since we cannot stop COâ‚‚ emissions immediately, we need to take short- and long-term measures. Either way, we need to transition towards a sustainable society. 

As suggested during the Conference on the Future of Europe, we must focus on the possibilities of generating energy through hydrogen and nuclear sources. The best solution would be to produce energy without COâ‚‚. Wind energy should be used for the production of green hydrogen and the EU should invest more in developing long-term renewable energy storage. 

Achieving decarbonisation is the most important objective for Volt. Nuclear energy is an essential energy source in decarbonisation for the EU and the whole world. As most trajectories compatible with a 1.5Â°C threshold rely on nuclear energy according to the latest IPCC report, nuclear energy will continue to play an essential role in climate change mitigation in the years to come. Thus, nuclear energy infrastructure investments are necessary for efficiency, safety, and innovation.

(Picture: http://volkskrant.nl)

Deze verkiezingen gaan over veel onderwerpen die jou aangaan: zoals ons klimaat, betaalbaar wonen, en de omschakeling naar een duurzame samenleving. Stem daarom op een nieuwe generatie in de politiek, die niet vooruitschuift maar doet! ğŸ’ª

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: How many languages have you learned in your life?ğŸ§ Most people would certainly mention their mother tongue and maybe additionally English.

Languages open up many opportunities and new perspectives. Especially in the European job market, the ability to speak several languages fluently is often demanded. 

However, languages also play a major role in connecting with people from other backgrounds, thus forming shared experiences and European identity. Therefore, the opportunities to learn languages should be distributed fairly and prioritized equally within the European Union.ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º

Many people do not know of the existence of exchange programmes such as â€œErasmusâ€ for apprentices. In addition, many people cannot afford voluntary student exchanges at school. 

Therefore, we share the opinion of the Conference on the Future of Europe, that the European Union needs to empower people to engage with their European identity. We recommend promoting multilingualism from an early age. For us, this means more and better information campaigns for potential Erasmus trainees as well as better marketing and financial support for the exchange programme. Eventually, this will pave the way for a European project by and for all people!ğŸ«‚

#Erasmus #multilingualism

Volt is strongly against plans to sell parts of the Port of Hamburg to the Chinese state-owned group COSCO.

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: What is the European Parliament currently doing? How did the elections in my neighbouring country turn out?ğŸ¤”

These are questions and topics that concern citizens throughout the European Union. However, in national news and media, there is little space for the European perspective. In some EU countries, there are also active attempts to prevent a change of perspective. 

However, freedom of expression, a fundamental value of the European Union, must include the possibility to inform oneself and spread one's own opinion. Thatâ€™s why media represented in all countries of the EU and reporting from a European perspective are essential to forming European public opinion. 

Therefore, we agree with the demand of the Conference on the Future of Europe that the European Union must commit itself to giving its citizens the possibility to be well and easily informed about what is happening within the European institutions and within Europe itself. 

We want to introduce you to some of the media that already exist and plead for an official European media network. ğŸ“»

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Although the EU has been built on economic foundations, there has been a growing interest over the last decade in the role that culture can play within the EU. 

Cultural programmes and exchanges are recognized as having a unifying effect, promoting diversity by encouraging decentralized initiatives; the processes of decentralization and democratization undertaken in certain countries; and raising citizens' awareness of development issues. 

The CoFE has focused on one specific objective regarding cultural exchanges: access and democratization of existing European programmes. In the report, the EU recognizes its responsibility to â€initiate, mediate, and fund cultural and social exchanges across the continentâ€. Indeed, the EU has set up several programs over the past decades to support job creation in culture (Europe Creative), regional development, education and vocational training (Erasmus+), and new information technologies (Horizon Europe). 

However, the EU notes that these are unfortunately not yet available to everyone and â€allows only a small percentage of European citizens to participateâ€. Therefore, a democratization initiative is taken into account to facilitate access to these opportunities for all citizens, of any age, level of education and financial capacity. 

The benefits of cultural exchange have been promoted by Volt from the beginning: to create a more connected, inclusive, federal and democratic Europe that encourages the active participation of citizens at every level.

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope wants to strengthen FRONTEX. We disagree.

The CoFE wants to strengthen FRONTEX to enable them to go to EU border regions and CoFE sees Frontex as a protector of human rights. Unfortunately, we have seen ample evidence that FRONTEX is not a protector of human rights. 

As FRONTEX remains accused of controversial push-back actions, Volt is sceptical of the COFE recommendation that FRONTEX should be awarded more power and independence, though COFE does recognise the need for full transparency.

We agree thereâ€™s a need for a strong external border to ensure orderly and humane access to the EU. We want an EU border protection system that receives asylum seekers in an orderly and humane way, upholds European values and ensures that the first points of contact with refugees exemplify what European citizens stand for.

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Protecting our Biodiversity â€” Biodiversity not only refers to the number of species within an ecosystem but also to the genetic diversity within the species' gene pool and the number of and interaction between different communities of species within a larger ecosystem. At the moment, each level is affected by human activity, and in many cases, this interaction results in a reduction in biodiversity. 

The panellists of the Conference on the future of Europe recognized this problem and called for a drastic reduction of chemical pesticides and fertilizers in all types of farming. By enforcing the application of high standards, accelerating the research on natural alternatives and supporting the adoption of new solutions. 

Similarly, Volt calls for a stop to excessive fertilizer use and the associated loss of species. Instead, we should promote initiatives that empower citizens, like urban gardening and sharing economies to reduce waste as well as support and develop enhanced education programs on biodiversity for all generations. 

(Picture: https://veeteelt.nl )

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: What exactly is the EU? What authorities does it have and whom does it represent? All these questions should be answered for young people during their educationâ€¦ and many more! However, this is not always the case. 

Although early and informative education about the European Union could counter populism and disinformation within the EU, its approach varies depending on the member states and their schooling system. It must be clear how significant the role of this education is. This is not only our opinion at Volt â€“ the 'Conference on the future of Europe' demands better knowledge sharing and education from the EU about its own institutions.

Do you agree with this? Do you find the European Union takes or has taken a big part in your education?

On the occasion of the legislative elections on 25 September, @voltitalia is collecting signatures in the foreign constituency of the Italian Parliament, representing Italian citizens living abroad.

With our proposals, we want to bring a young, new and European energy to the Italian Parliament, which has been entrenched for too many years and stuck between balances of power and fears of collapse.

Supporting us with a signature is simple and allows new forces to attempt the electoral race.

A right, that of political participation, is too often forgotten and cornered in Italy by bureaucratic difficulties.

Een kleine groep wordt rijker, terwijl de rijen voor de voedselbank langer worden. 

We dringen al maanden bij het Kabinet aan op maatregelen die de koopkracht van de midden- en lage inkomensgroepen dit jaar nog zouden helpen. Maar de coalitie blokkeerde elke beweging ten gunste van die mensen waarvan we wisten dat ze zonder gerichte hulp in de diepe ellende terecht zouden komen.

We kunnen niet meer wachten. Het is nu tijd voor een inflatietoeslag via de zorgtoeslag, een Europese winstbelasting, voor een experiment met basisinkomen, voor een Europees afschalingsplan, voor gratis schoollunches & menstruatieproducten voor scholieren, en voor de overstap naar een groene samenleving. 

Want zoals we deze zomer zagen, met overstromingen, bosbranden en droogte: het klimaat kan zeker niet wachten.

We strongly condemn the new act of aggression on the part of Russia and the invasion of Ukraine. This is a blatant breach of international law that cannot be justified!
Our thoughts are with the people of Ukraine who are now facing suffering and death because of the Kremlin's imperialist ambitions.
Now we as Europeans must stand united, make a clear commitment to peace and stand in solidarity behind Ukraine.
We must not allow moving borders by military means to be an option in Europe.
We therefore demand strict measures and sanctions against all Russian politicians, military officers, banks, companies, their business partners and people connected to the Kremlin involved in order to force an end to the military escalation. In addition, assets should be frozen and deals with Russian state-owned companies cancelled.
In addition, there is also a need to support Ukraine directly, to provide humanitarian aid and to take in refugees.
Today and in the coming days, we are showing solidarity with Ukraine in cities and towns across Europe and taking part in rallies for peace.
There should never be war in Europe again!
In this context, we also welcome the protests against the war in various Russian cities.

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Reducing Waste â€“ We exploit, produce value, and then throw it away. Our existing economic model operates in this manner, and it is completely unsustainable. It is unjust to people who are harmed by brutal working conditions or polluted living environments. It's also unjust to future generations, who won't be able to use the resources we're squandering.

We must move toward a circular economy, as called for by participants at the Conference on the Future of Europe, with financial incentives for those who comply aimed at both corporations and citizens. Participants also urged that the EU go above and beyond to allow customers to keep products for extended periods. Our disposable, single-use society cannot be sustained. Manufacturers should be forced to indicate their products' projected lifespan. In exchange, the EU should provide information on how to re-use and repair things, such as through the internet and education.

What do you do to re-use, reduce and recycle? 

(Picture: http://agro-chemie.nl)

De Nederlandse regering maakt een wet om vluchtelingen in Nederland te spreiden, maar houdt eerlijke verdeling in de EU tegen. Staatssecretaris Van der Burg wilde de Dublinverordening weer op tafel te krijgen via geitenpaadjes in de wet. Waar veel experts al voor waarschuwden bleek te kloppen, toen hij vorige week werd teruggefloten door de rechter.
 
Volt heeft een Europees lange termijn plan. Geen geitenpaadjes in de wet, maar de crisis duurzaam oplossen met een akkoord over een gemeenschappelijk Europees Asiel- en Migratiepact. 

Totdat Europa met een oplossing komt, zal er nooit grip op migratie plaatsvinden. Mensen hebben recht op asiel en moeten daar ten alle tijden aanspraak op kunnen maken.

Yesterday, Germany celebrated the #reunification that occurred in 1990 between West Germany and East Germany. While reunification was a success, Volt pleads for increased attention to economic differences and points to lessons for Europe as a whole.

People growing up in the two German nations were raised in opposing political, economic, and social circumstances. West was capitalist and democratic, and East was communist and dictatorial. The tensions of the Cold War meant few Germans believed they would live to see their country unite.

But, just as history had separated the Germans, it was the history that brought them back together. The 80s saw a collapse of faith in the communist system. East Germans, demanding change, pursued a peaceful revolution in 1989 that saw the Berlin wall torn down and the #DDR regime collapse. A year later, guided by West German chancellor Helmut Kohl and members of what is today the EU, German reunification became a fact. 

Reunification is a process that is still ongoing today. Privatisation of the planned economy in East Germany led to 3 million lost jobs. Although the economy recovered and grew, economic differences between the regions persist, and people living in the eastern part of the country still feel underrepresented in national politics. In this regard, #Volt pleads for increased dialogue between citizens and politics and strives to bridge the economic gap to allow every citizen to fully benefit from regional and international trade and cooperation

Overall, though, German reunification has been a success. Two countries that at many points seemed close to war, integrated into a democratic and peaceful whole. Germanyâ€™s example inspires Volt to strive for increased European cooperation on all fronts. Let us bridge the economic gaps between the European East and West, caused by the dividing line of the Iron Wall. Let us bridge the political gaps, safeguarding democracy at all costs. Let us most importantly learn how reunification came to be: mutual respect, dialogue, and the acceptance of differences. Together, we can achieve great things. Alone, we achieve only isolation. 

#GermanUnityDay

â€œWomen, Life, Freedomâ€: Volt stands in solidarity with Iranian women and calls for an end to violence by the government!

On September 16th, Jina Mahsa Amini was arrested and beaten to death by the morality police in Tehran for not wearing the hijab properly in accordance with the Islamic Republicâ€™s laws.
In the wake of Jina Mahsa Aminiâ€™s death, #protests erupted in unprecedented intensity. What started as a protest against the mandatory hijab rules and for womenâ€™s rights, has become something much larger: people are standing up against years of oppression by an authoritarian regime. 

Modern #Iran is no stranger to large protests, but the scale and nature of the current protests are unique. While women and young people in their 20s are leading the protests, Iranians in the country and outside have united behind them not only in solidarity but in fighting for their fundamental rights and freedom as well.

Although the protesters are unarmed, the government is using excessive violence to crack down on dissonance. Thousands of arrests and dozens of killings have been reported, and internet use has been severely restricted.

Volt Europa strongly condemns the violence by the regime and fully supports the fight of all Iranians for equal rights and freedom. We call on Volters to help us amplify the Iranian voices by collectively sharing information about the protests on social media and elsewhere.

We call on media outlets not to give a stage to the Iranian regimeâ€™s narrative but instead to provide a platform to the Iranian people and human rights experts. We urge the #EU and US to prioritise their support to by-pass the internet shutdowns by the Iranian government and to impose economic sanctions on and pursue prosecution of regime officials involved in the violation of human rights.

Change is possible. With each day of protests and each courageous woman walking the streets unveiled, the newfound self-confidence of Iranians becomes more and more irreversible. Volt Europa stands in solidarity with the citizens of Iran on their path to freedom!
#MahsaAmini #iranianwomen #iranprotests

Volt applauds the European Parliamentâ€™s decision to reject granting a 2020 budget discharge to the EUâ€™s Border Guard Agency, Frontex.

The denial of discharge to #Frontex is a win for democracy after a series of internal fights. The Parliament finally sends a strong signal: no EU agency should be complicit in human rights violations. Volt, together with our MEP, has been calling for greater accountability and transparency of all EU agencies, and in particular Frontex. 

Reports show that Frontex and its top management are responsible for numerous internal dysfunctions and ignored violations of human rights carried out on behalf of the national authorities. The sad reality is that thousands of refugees have been affected by Frontexâ€™ illegal practices. That is a failure of our democracy and of the upholding of the rule of law. 

We advocate for a common and humane migration and asylum policy in the EU. It is also in desperate need of a transparent mechanism to hold institutions accountable. We call on the EU to take this evidence seriously and to address the Member Statesâ€™ active engagement in pushbacks at the external border.

Read more here: https://medium.com/volt-europa/frontex-violations-of-human-rights-1c6929bf24f5

This week marks a year since Russiaâ€™s illegal invasion in Ukraine, which started on the night of February 24th 2022. It is a week of remembrance - remembrance of the Peace we lost, the people affected, the tragedies occurred.

But it is also a week to re-energise our support to Ukraine! They have shown incredible resilience, strength, and heroism in the face of Russian aggression. We can be proud of ourselves, too, for coming together as a Party and as Europe to show unwavering support to our European siblings in need.

Let us take this opportunity to reinforce our belief in the spirit of cooperation and peace. Ask yourself the question: WHAT CAN I DO FOR UKRAINE? Even if we feel powerless, there is always something we can do.

We can share information, reminding our bubbles of Ukraineâ€™s struggles and their need for our support. We can affect policy by voting, protesting, or writing letters. We can open our arms to refugees, or donate money and material to supply the unbeatable Ukrainian people with the things they need to withstand the difficult times they face.

Together, we can make a real difference! Take the opportunity this week to reflect on a year of war, and to reinforce your belief in a brighter future, together, for Europe and the Ukrainian people!

Jacinda Ardern, New Zealandâ€™s female ex-PM, is an inspiration to Volt. The lessons we can learn from her are plenty, but the main one is this: WE NEED MORE WOMEN IN POLITICS!

Read the full article on Medium (link in bio and story)

Volt takes the view that bringing women into politics (and keeping them there) requires a broad approach to womenâ€™s societal roles in general. Necessary steps include:

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ«Mentoring and training: Supporting women working in sectors in which they are underrepresented (such as politics)
ğŸš¼Access to childcare: Providing high-quality, affordable support
ğŸ“œRatification of the Istanbul Convention: Ending persistent discrimination and violence against women and minorities

For Volt Europa Co-President, Francesca Romana Dâ€™Antuono, Ardernâ€™s empathic leadership style represented â€˜a new way of doing politics: more humane and caring, but not weak; the kind of leadership we need to meet the challenges of our modern times.â€™

The reality is that women remain very much in a minority in all political spheres. Across the EU, just over 30 per cent of MPs of national governments are women. 

Volt makes a point of ensuring gender-balance within its own internal structures. According to its statutes, the Board of Volt must be gender-balanced, while each formal position in the European team must be shared between a male/non-binary and female/non-binary Volt member.

â€˜How can we believe that we are going to build a resilient and thriving society without the perspective of half of the population?â€™, asks Francesca Romana Dâ€™Antuono.

By showing the world that there is a different way of doing politics, Jacinda Ardern allowed politically-active women to feel legitimised in a sphere that remains, sadly, hostile to them. Now that she has made her exit (at least for the time being), it is up to us to ensure that we take her example. If we do not, we will continue to approach the worldâ€™s problems underprepared and under-resourced, without the knowledge, insights and perspectives of half the worldâ€™s people.

Last week we kicked off the #VoicesOfIran campaign, lending our channels to Iranians to amplify their voices. Democracy dies in darkness but may be born in light. So, we call on you to talk to Iranians in your network - see what you can do to help them speak up safely!

All Iranian protesters want to get basic rights: The right to freedom in things like religion, information, and clothing. To have a voice in the politics of your country. To equality between women and men. These are the same values we fight to protect as a European party, and that we wish to promote around the globe. 

This time, we spoke to an Iranian woman, who has recently come to Europe for research and study.

What do you think the EU/world can do to help the women of Iran?

The following proposals would help us in our struggle:
#1 Non-recognition of Iranian ambassadors and government anymore to support people's protest
#2 Targeted Sanctions of Iran: Blocking assets and deporting influential government officials from Europe and other countries. This does more than full economic sanctions on Iran, which would put pressure on the Iranian people
#3 Grant Iranian refugees in the EU the same status and access as Ukrainian refugees
#4 Improving conditions and providing better facilities for getting a resident permit for all Iranians who want to live outside the country

What is your hope for the future of Iran?

I hope Iran can be free and the protest will finally help overcome the current constraints. We want basic rights like freedom of speech and thought, freedom of religion, and especially freedom for women to wear what they want, permission to go to another country, to study, to work, and to live.

What are your feelings right now?

Although I am fearful about the uncertainty of the future, now, I want to be our voice, to support the people of my country to get them the rights that we deserve. What I deeply want is that the killing and imprisonment of innocent people will stop as soon as possible to end the terror.

Thanks again @neyestanimana for the striking illustration.

Volt wants sustainable agriculture in all of Europe. We believe a European wide CO2 tax including on agriculture and a reform of the Common Agricultural Policy is an important step in this transformation. Furthermore, we want to phase out subsidies for all agricultural practices that degrade soil, cause erosion or load water bodies with harmful chemicals. Subsidies must be directed toward any agricultural practices that improve topsoil, capture GHGs, protect water bodies, promote biodiversity, and stop or reverse erosion.

To accomplish all of this Volt is sharing best practices across the continent, so we can move all of Europe forward in the green transition.

The European Parliament celebrated its 70th birthday yesterday!

The democratic body of the European Union was not always known as the European Parliament. It started as the Common Assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community. From these early beginnings, the European Parliament has evolved, adapted, and transformed into the body we know today.

Democracies and institutions are never static. Over time, the European Parliament has fought for more responsibilities and powers within the EU. This is necessary for democratic legitimacy. The EP, directly elected, represents the will of the people, and is the mechanism by which the executive Commission and Council are held accountable.

Roberta Metsola, the current EP President, highlighted the fact that the European Parliament is â€œthe only multilingual, multi-party, transnational parliament in the worldâ€. So many nationalities, cultural backgrounds, political ideologies, languages, and people are represented in this organ of democracy.

Voltâ€™s Member of the European Parliament, @damian.boeselager represents the voters of Volt in this complex system. Allying with the European Greens, he pleads for increased regulation of artificial intelligence, and for a more European approach to dealing with migration and border security. Just this last week a law negotiated by Damien was passed in the EP called RePower EU, this law gives more financial support to EU countries, their citizens and companies struggling with high energy prices. Yesterday, he addressed Parliament about the dangers of strongmen such as Hungaryâ€™s Viktor OrbÃ¡n and argued that the Commission should withhold funds from Hungary for their descent into autocracy and their support for Russia.

It is an honour that, in these 70 years, Volt has earned a place in the history of the European Parliament. For the elections in 2024, we aim to make a mark and expand our number of seats, so that we can make even more work of improving the Union and making it more cohesive and progressive!

#EuropeanParliament #Europe #EU #EP

Bij @omroepwnl pleitte ik zondag voor een meevallersheffing voor grote energiebedrijven. ğŸ¥

We willen af van Russisch gas, maar dan moeten we wel voorkomen dat we terugvallen op oude gewoontes. Heropen dus geen kolencentrales en pomp ook geen Gronings gas op. Want als we dat doen, belanden we straks weer in de volgende crisis omdat we de klimaatdoelen niet halen. Juist nu het moeilijk wordt moeten we blijven kiezen voor de lange termijn en de #energietransitie versnellen.

En laten we ervoor zorgen dat de energietransitie ook een sociale transitie is. Zowel huishoudens met lage- Ã©n middeninkomens maken zich zorgen omdat de energiekosten steeds hoger worden, terwijl energiebedrijven grote miljardenwinsten zijn blijven maken.

Daarom wil Volt een meevallersheffing, naar het voorbeeld van Spanje, ItaliÃ« en het Verenigd Koninkrijk. Een meevallersheffing houdt in dat je de winst van de grote energiebedrijven eenmalig extra belast. De miljarden extra belastinginkomsten kunnen we vervolgens gebruiken om de mensen die het meest te lijden hebben onder de hoge energiekosten te compenseren, of om bijvoorbeeld sociale huurwoningen te isoleren.

Volt stands strongly in solidarity with the people of Iran in their fight for freedom. For weeks now, the Iranian government has been using excessive force to repress protestors, who took to the streets following the death of Mahsa Amini at the hands of the Iranian religious police.

Since then, there are reports of dozens, if not hundreds more deaths as the authoritarian Iranian elite try to cling to power using violence. Recently, the murder of a 17-year-old freedom fighter, Nika Shakarami, sparked headlines around the world and fuelled the peopleâ€™s resistance.

To show our support to the protestors, we will be promoting the voice of the Iranian people on our channels in the coming weeks. In this first post, we asked two Iranian women to share their thoughts on the protests. We have hidden their names for the sake of their safety.

What are your feelings right now?

Person 1: â€œI am devastatedâ€¦â€
Person 2: â€œI have 2 different feelings at the same time: Iâ€™m so sad because of what is happening in Iran right now and during the last 43 years. On the other side, Iâ€™m so happy to see young people are amazingly brave, fighting for their basic rights and supporting each other. This generation is wonderful, no word can explain their bravery!

What is your hope for the future?

Person 1: â€œâ€¦to get rid of the Islamic Republic.â€
Person 2: â€œHistory of Iran is full of sad days, but nothing will remain foreverâ€¦it will change soon or late because the sun canâ€™t stay behind clouds always. We have hope and we will fight for our hope to come true!â€

What do you think the EU / world can do to help you? 

Person 1: â€œI expect them to stop tolerating the Islamic Republic. Take an action such as to summon the Islamic republic ambassadors, etc.â€
Person 2: â€œAll of the sanctions till now, we're just against people and made their life harder though the government were free and abusing these sanctions to torture people more. The world has to forget the benefits of oil business with the corrupted government of Iran and stay with the people even if it has no economic benefits for them!â€

Thanks to talented Iranian artist @neyestanimana for letting us use his illustration.

#VoicesOfIran

ENGLISH
Volt will fight to bring Denmark's justice system out of its current crisis. More resources are needed: We have too few judges and too many pending cases. We need to close the revolving door between politicians and business and increase transparency in society. Transparency can be improved with a lobby register and the revolving door can be removed with a 2-year quarantine for politicians as Volt got implemented in the Netherlands.
These shortcomings are among others pointed out in the EU Commission's Rule of Law Report 2022 and in Weekendavisen 21/10-2022 a picture of a justice system in a long term crisis emerges that lacks resources.
In the last couple of election campaigns politicians have promised increased sentences putting even more pressure on the system. We need an overhaul not symbolic gestures.

The next personal story in the #VoltersStories series comes from Matthias Iannis Portelli:
I joined Volt as I felt tired and politically homeless in Malta. To me, it felt as if the country had administrative-type politicians, that lacked vision and hunger to better the country, and this to me came as a relief when I stumbled upon Volt.
 
ğŸ¤ Volt is a community.
 
Volt truly brings people from different walks of life together. However, what fascinates me the most, is that the members are from both sides of the spectrum, from centre-left to centre-right. 
The fact that Volt operates in this centrist manner from its prime ideology based on reason and pragmatism, as to attempt to reconcile the left and right wing under one single entity through its fundamental challenges that act in a way as its values, is extremely seductive for me, and something I believe makes us unique.
 
ğŸ“– Volt is a way of life.
 
The wealth of skills the volunteer community possesses gives way to all its members learning new things. Either through Volt Academy, workshops, events, colleague interactions, or interacting with challenges. 
 
Since I've been a member I've learned a great deal about politics, public speaking, lobbying, public relations, campaigning, and policy writing, as well as applying what I'm learning in class into actual practice and being more aware and educated when it comes to taboo topics like abortion. I would probably not have known much nor felt as comfortable as I do if it wasnâ€™t through VoltMalta, particularly Arnas and Alexia.
 
Above all, Volt's Progressivist Philosophy enshrouded in centrism provides the means to reconcile, and understand the different realities that shape our world. Even if some might not agree with everything we believe in, it gives way to a discussion which is healthy for politics and society.
 
With this, I'd like to end with: 
Volt is an opportunity to regain much-needed confidence in politics. For the most part, traditional politics has made people complacent, resulting in political apathy and creating a loop of political mockery and fruitless arguments. It is an opportunity to change local and European politics.

Wij brengen oplossingen en een positief geluid. Dat doen we al in Europa, de Tweede Kamer en lokaal. Nu is het tijd voor ons geluid in de provincie. ğŸ’œâš¡

When is enough going to really be enough?

We all remember all too well when the body of 2-year-old Alan Kurdi washed up on the shores of Turkey in 2015. EU governments vouched then to â€œnever againâ€ let this happen and promised to come up with a well-functioning European system that has solidarity at its heart. 

Fast forward 8 years and this painful history continues to repeat itself on the Bulgarian border and off the coast of Italy. These are not standalone incidents, they are the consequence of a migration policy that focuses more on building bigger barriers and forcing asylum seekers to take dangerous routes to get to Europe. 

The only solution is a structural solution: we need to ensure that search and rescue efforts are effective, solidarity mechanisms are in place, and legal migration routes are provided. 

Read more about how we can make #migration safer, supportive and more effective - link in bio!

We moeten van mooie woorden naar daden. Terwijl onze CO2-uitstoot blijft groeien, zijn er landen waar de klimaatschade al zo groot is, dat mensen op de vlucht moeten. Wir restrukturieren die Eisenbahninfrastrukturunternehmen (EIU) des Bundes. #VoltPoliticalPriorities: ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º Voltâ€™s primary goal is to make the European Union more democratic!

Willy Brandt, a German chancellor, once said â€œWir wollen mehr Demokratie wagenâ€ (we want to dare more democracy). This quote rings true today. The most voted-for policy issue at our GA concerned the topic of democracy in the EU. For this, reform is necessary. Instead of being a union of heads of state, the EU should be a union of citizens. 

ğŸ“In our vision, the European Parliament needs to have the right to initiate laws, like other parliaments in national spheres. To ensure that the European Parliament more accurately reflects the will of the European citizens, EP elections need to be Europeanised. Currently, EP elections too often function as midterm national elections. This must change - let the people vote for European parties with European candidates, on European issues. 

ğŸ¤The Spitzenkandidaten system, where leaders of parties run officially for President of the Commission, should gain more prominence. The citizens must decide who becomes the face of the EU, not the heads of state in a back-door deal. This will immediately grant the EU more democratic legitimacy, as the voice of the people will be honoured.

Volt wants to establish a true European government. One that answers to the European Parliament, and thus to the European people. One government that is capable of solving crises without worrying about vetoes from uncooperating states.

Steps are being taken in this regard. Treaty reform has been agendized by both Emmanuel Macron and Olaf Scholz. Germany lowered the legal age to vote in EP elections to 16 this week. We encourage these developments and cheer on leaders who see that the challenges of tomorrow can only be tackled through European cooperation supported by informed and engaged European demos.

If you want to commit yourself to create a more democratic European Union, join Volt today! Sign up to become a member on our website, and share our posts on your channels to help us grow!

Recently, Voltâ€™s members in the Amsterdam city council proposed a campaign to preserve energy: Doors closed, lights off! (#zaakgeslotenlichtuit). 

Europe is facing the biggest energy crisis of a century. Everywhere, families are forced to pay double, sometimes triple what they did last year to keep the heat on in their homes. Industries are facing shutdowns that endanger food security, and threaten entire sectors of the economy. 

Meanwhile, big corporate offices and businesses across Europe keep their lights on even when nobody is in the building. This has to stop. 

Another factor is climate change. Energy supply in Europe is currently still often reliant on fossil fuels that are driving temperature rise. Every second spent with lights on in places that have no need for them, is a second closer to the scenario where this earth will not be liveable for millions of species, and in the worst case: us. 

Voltâ€™s initiative got support from the Amsterdam city councillors, and it is now being explored what judicial powers the municipality has to force business owners to shut their lights off after closing. 

We applaud @volt.amsterdam for this great and necessary measure to conserve energy, and plead for other cities and countries and Europe to follow their example. Together, we can make sure Europe comes out of this crisis stronger, greener, and more resilient! 

#amsterdam, #amsterdamcitycouncil, #energycrisis, #climatecrisis, #saveenergy, #turnoffthelights, #EU, #europe

We need a real European High-Speed Rail Network! ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡ºğŸš„
European rail travel is a key component for a carbon-neutral future! To read more about our proposed solutions, click on the link in our story!

The birthplace of the train has neglected to improve its rail infrastructure. Whereas China has built the worldâ€™s largest integrated national high-speed rail network in 30 years, Europe only has a few loose pockets of HSR that are badly connected.

âœˆï¸ As a result, most Europeans fly to get to other places in the Union. This is bad in many regards, primarily because COâ‚‚ emissions per kilometre travelled are 6-8 times higher than that of rail. Without decarbonising, aviation could account for 22% of all global COâ‚‚ emissions by 2050.

Meanwhile, we live on a small, densely populated continent eminently suitable for fast rail connections. So what can be done? We offer a perspective on how it could be improved:

ğŸ“± Make it easier to book international trains in one integrated European app

ğŸ›« Make it less expensive by increasing taxes on aviation while reducing them on the rail, and using that money to invest in HSR

ğŸ‘® There should be an EU rail authority to oversee international connections to ensure proper transfer possibilities and fewer regional stops

ğŸš„ Invest significantly in European rail infrastructure, first by connecting the major HSR hubs (France, Spain, Italy), then by expanding the HSR network.

Improvement is very possible. The European Commission already set itself the goal to increase Europeâ€™s rail travel market share by double in 2030, and triple in 2050. Volt believes more urgency must be felt and pleads for an integral, European vision to connect the citizens of Europe in a fair and green way.

#EuropeanInfrastructure #HighSpeedRail #TrainTravel

The far-right Finns Party, who form part of Finland's coalition government, are the latest populist party to scrap their plans to leave the EU.

They're joining a long list of eurosceptic parties across Europe who have done the same, such as Marine Le Pen's National Rally in France, and the Five Star Movement in Italy.

While these parties remain eurosceptic, none of them want to leave the EU. Instead, they want to see more EU reforms.

Why have these parties scrapped their plans to leave the EU? Simple, it's not a vote winner. Brexit has highlighted to voters across Europe the chaos that would happen to their country if they chose to leave the EU.

The EU isn't perfect, but you don't fix it by leaving it.

#eu #europe #brexit #uk #volteuropa

Heute gedenken wir allen Verfolgten und Opfern des Nationalsozialismus. In der mehr als 12 Jahre andauernden Schreckens- und Gewaltherrschaft wurden mehr als 6 Millionen JÃ¼dinnen*Juden und hunderttausende Sinti*zze und Rom*nja ermordet. Im Gedenken an die industriellen Massenmorde wird seitdem an Schoa und Porajmos erinnert. 

Auch wurden Hunderttausende Menschen aufgrund ihrer Religion, ihrer sexuellen oder politischen Orientierung, ihres nicht binÃ¤ren Geschlechtes oder ihrer Behinderung inhaftiert, sterilisiert oder ermordet. 
Im Vernichtungslager Auschwitz allein ermordeten die Nationalsozialist*innen mehr als 1,1 Millionen JÃ¼dinnen*Juden durch Mord, Hunger oder Krankheit. Nur wenige HÃ¤ftlinge konnten nach der Befreiung des Lagers am 27. Januar 1945 durch die Rote Armee gerettet werden und Ã¼berlebten. 

Als Nachfolgestaat des NS-Regimes trifft Deutschland eine besondere Verantwortung. Auch 78 Jahre nach der Befreiung von Auschwitz ist die BekÃ¤mpfung von Antisemitismus dringend notwendig. Antisemitische Ã„uÃŸerungen und VerschwÃ¶rungstheorien nehmen in weiten Teilen der Gesellschaft wieder zu und werden zum Teil als Kritik an Israel getarnt. Es ist daher die Aufgabe von allen, dieser demokratiefeindlichen Entwicklung entgegenzutreten und nicht nur den Verbrechen der Vergangenheit zu gedenken.

Aus diesem Grund kommt Volt Deutschland am 27. Januar zusammen, um in Potsdam den Opfern des Nationalsozialismus zu gedenken. Vom Nuthepark fÃ¼hrt eine stille Demonstration zum Brandenburger Tor und endet dort mit einer Kundgebung. Die Veranstaltung beginnt um 18:00 Uhr.

Politicians and policy writers today face many complex topics to make decisions on: the rise of AI, climate change policy, the race to create advanced micro-chips, critical decisions about the future of European industry - but also classic challenges like infrastructure, building, and the economy.

Earlier this month, MEPs, advocates and academics met to discuss policies for sustainable prosperity in Europe at the #BeyondGrowth conference. 

Much of the debate on future sustainability focuses on either degrowth, scaling down the scope of our economic activities, or on green growth, decoupling economic growth from environmental destruction. This debate is certainly justified but we should rather focus on the type and characteristics of growth we seek in society. 

And since the European Union represents around 16% of the World economy, the EU can and should lead the way to drive degrowth and green growth to the benefit of all economies, including todayâ€™s lower-income countries. Let's lay down the tracks now, so that all economies can grow and grow sustainably through:

ğŸ’° EU corporate taxation: The green transition needs to be financed. The EU needs to introduce EU-wide tax harmonisation, ultimately leading to European corporate taxes that can be centrally invested. This taxation should be progressive by turnover.
âš¡ï¸EU energy market: The EU needs to move to a single, renewable-first energy market. The union must regulate towards achieving this goal.
ğŸ¤EU subsidy: The EU news to stop subsidising unsustainable business practices, and heavily subsidise sustainable practices, be it in agriculture, energy generation or industry. 

Growth is not the goal - a sustainable environment isğŸ’šğŸŒ±

The 2022 World Cup will will start this week in Qatar. The Arab nation won the rights to host it back in 2010, but since then, it has come under heavy criticism for human rights violations and other scandals.

Migrant workers, often from poor countries, were brought to Qatar and forced to work gruelling hours under terrible conditions. Their passports were taken, they slept with dozens cramped in tiny rooms, and they laboured under the blasting Arabian sun. Thousands have died, something the Qatari government has tried to sweep under the rug.

Qatar has also faced criticism for its harsh crackdown on LGBT rights. LGBT Qataris face up to 7 years in jail. A Qatari official recently said in an interview that being LGBT is a result of "damage in the mind".

The Qatari authorities have suppressed any criticism of the government. If caught, Qatari citizens face imprisonment, and foreign nationals face deportation.

Qatar won the World Cup bid with bribes. FIFA admitted awarding it to Qatar was a â€œmistakeâ€.

Volt stands in strong opposition to the Qatari government's human rights violations, and condemns FIFA for allowing the World Cup, the most high profile event in world sports, to be hosted under such conditions. Women make up for half of the population but this is still not reflected in our European parliaments. Often enough only a third of the politicians in the national chambers are female â€“ sometimes more, mostly less.

On todayâ€™s International Womenâ€™s Day we would like to show you a few of our many female Volt members from all over Europe who took on the responsibility to change this.

In Volt, we installed various systemic measures to improve equality between genders, for example all our team lead roles always consist of two persons of different genders. 

Every woman has the same right to a place at the governing tables as men do, despite society telling them otherwise for centuries and centuries.

Discrimination of gender is as outdated as doing politics from a national perspective. We at Volt want to get rid of both.

Join the change, show your face and help us pave the way to an equal, to a feminist European future.

#IWD #feminism #WomenOfVolt

As the year draws to a close, it is time to reflect on the progress we have made together!
ğŸ”—> Read more on our Medium through the link in our bio and story!

2022 has been a big year for our party. We ran in 4 national elections and 4 regional elections, and set up various new national chapters. We surpassed the threshold of 25,000 Volters, and now have a total of 115 elected officials.

The next year promises to be an exciting one. We are kicking off new national parties in Lithuania and Latvia. Greece and Switzerland will hold national elections in summer, and Poland on the municipal level. On Monday, 200 countries signed a landmark accord at the UNâ€™s COP15 summit in Montreal. The goal of the accord is to prevent biodiversity loss in the worldâ€™s land and oceans. As a result of human-induced climate change, life on earth as we know it is entering a mass extinction event - the first since the one that wiped the dinosaurs off the face of the earth.

The accord sets out to protect 30% of the planetâ€™s nature by 2030. With financial measures to help developing countries, the COP15 accord is a step in the right direction for minimizing the damage we inflict on the worldâ€™s biodiversity.

This accord is a good start, but it cannot be the end of humanityâ€™s conservation efforts. Volt has several policies aimed at preserving biodiversity in Europe, and encourages preservation efforts across the globe.

ğŸSupport the conservation of wild species, particularly key species like bees
ğŸ„Increase the quantity and quality of protected areas by reducing the size of agricultural areas through more effective methods of food production
ğŸ’°Acceptance of our responsibility as developed countries to help developing countries deal with the fallout of climate change
ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ«Educate our citizens on more sustainable consumer habits

Read more about Voltâ€™s policies to protect biodiversity on our Medium page [link in bio]

Forums like COP15 provide a good place for dialogue between nations, and Volt is encouraged by the increasing awareness across the globe of the urgency with which we must tackle climate change. There is much work to be done, but facing it with utmost pragmatism and optimism goes a long way in creating the atmosphere in which change can be made!

Purchase fairly-produced Volt merch from our store [link in bio] and let the World know that you care about the Planet and care about the future of Europe. Put on our T-shirts and hoodies or take a purple tote bag with you to show that you support our pan-European, pragmatic and progressive political party. 

We have carefully selected a handful of organic and fairly produced garments in white, grey, and purple featuring the Volt logo with or without a rainbow background. 

Your orders will be delivered by Green Shirts, a social eco-wear company selling high-quality sustainable and vegan clothing. A political statement has never been so stylish and comfortable, so why wait with your purchase?

This morning, a historic earthquake shook Turkiye and Syria. So far, it is clear that thousands of buildings have collapsed, leaving untold damage and countless victims. 

Our thoughts are with the people of Turkiye and Syria. This severe tragedy calls for a broad international response. Echoing the EU's activation of the Civil Protection Mechanism, we call on all European governments to send aid, rescue workers and full support to the regions struck by the earthquake.

A disaster like this is a time to lay politics aside and focus on what is important: saving lives. We hope that regardless of the geopolitical challenges we all face, the spirit of human cooperation is placed first.

#Turkey #Turkiye #Syria #Earthquake #Europe #DisasterRelief #Aid #RedCross

A great day for #PayTransparency in the EU!

Better pay transparency is the first - essential - step to ensure everyone is paid fairly for their qualifications and skills and today, the European Parliament approved new rules to improve this across the EU:

What is more important? Coal or the Climate? 

ğŸ›¢ï¸Since this week, preparations for the evacuation of LÃ¼tzerath, Germany are underway. The reason is the fact that the town sits on top of the largest brown coal (lignite) deposit in Europe. Germany is one of the last European countries to still use brown coal for energy, even though it is the most polluting and least efficient way to produce energy compared to alternatives like gas, wind, or nuclear. Huge amounts of CO2 are produced, and ecosystems are destroyed.

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ”¬LÃ¼tzerath has become a symbol for the coal phase-out 2030 and thus the compliance with the Paris Agreement. According to the German Institute for Economic Research, the coal under LÃ¼tzerath is only needed if Germany still relies on coal after 2030. But that would go hand in hand with exceeding 1.5 degrees of global warming, and show an unwillingness to transform to a green economy.

ğŸ˜¡The German and North-Rhein Westphalia state governments insist that LÃ¼tzerath must be mined: More lignite is to be used in 2023 & 2024. This is justified by the loss of Russian gas. However, studies have shown that the mining of further villages is not necessary, especially since because of the warm winter European gas reserves are much higher than anticipated. 

ğŸŒ±The switch should now instead be made to cleaner alternatives. The situation is symbolic but clear: mining lignite endangers the 1.5 degree limit and goes against the pledges by the German government and Europe as a whole. What happens with LÃ¼tzerath shows whether Germany is committed to the climate goals.

ğŸ’œThis issue affects all of Europe. Germany is one of the blocâ€™s core economies. If it continues to run on dirty coal, that means all of our economies continue to run on dirty coal. Volt takes a strong stand against the proliferation of fossil fuels, and we fight for increased attention to green alternatives for energy!

ğŸ’™ğŸ’› A year since Russiaâ€™s illegal invasion of Ukraine, in which Putin set out to destroy Ukraine and its national identity, Ukraineâ€™s people are stronger and more united than ever!

From the beginning, everyone came together and showed the most amazing things humanity is capable of: love, compassion, strength, heroism, sacrifice, courage, cooperation - a desire to protect.

They helped the world rediscover these attributes too - across Europe, Ukrainian people mobilised support, organising protests, fundraisers; selling items so they can donate the proceeds to those in Ukraine who desperately need the worldâ€™s help. 

Ukraine and its people have been an inspiration to us. From President Zelenskyâ€™s heroic leadership, to Olegâ€™s fight in the trenches, to Natashaâ€™s crafting and selling of Ukrainian flags. The sacrifices they are making for European freedom and democracy will be remembered for generations to come.

Let us take this day to mourn the victims of this terrible war. But let us also take this day to remember what incredible spirit the Ukrainians have shown the world, and to thank them for being such a brightly shining star in a world which now seems so full of darkness.

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º Women make up half of the population but this is still not reflected in our European parliaments. Often enough only a third of the politicians in the national chambers are female â€“ sometimes more, mostly less.

On today's International Women's Day we would like to show you a few of our many female Volt members from all over Europe who took on the responsibility to change this.

In Volt, we installed various systemic measures to improve equality between genders, for example, all our team lead roles always consist of two persons of different genders. 

Every woman has the same right to a place at the governing tables as men, despite society telling them otherwise for centuries and centuries.

Discrimination of gender is as outdated as doing politics from a national perspective. We at Volt want to get rid of both.

Join the change, show your face and help us pave the way to an equal, to a feminist European future.

Last weekend the GA of Volt Europa took place in Prague, Volt Switzerland participated with a small delegation. Between all the speeches and panels, there was also time for socialising with fellow Volters. Additionally, the Public Action on Saturday evening was a great opportunity to do some sightseeing while simultaneously showing solidarity with Ukraine. All in all 750 Volters from all over Europe travelled to Prague, making it the biggest GA in the still young history of Volt. The Czech Team and the Events Team of Volt Europe did a great job in organising a wonderful event that sadly ended way too fast.

The debate on pension reform in #France has clearly shown that a systemic reform taking into account all challenges of todayâ€™s society is much needed.

Issues like climate change, our ageing population, migration, the digital transition or inequality are all interconnected and should be factored in any forward-thinking pension reform. 

Increased heatwaves and storms could worsen life expectancy rates, the ageing population will leave France in need of almost 4 million workers by 2050, technology advancements will revolutionise the workplace in ways we have yet to discover and finally, inequalities in the pension system do not provide a good solution to people with long or interrupted careers.

At Volt, we believe that the EU can help us overcome the short-term vision that too often characterises national politics. We therefore propose to launch a consultation for a systemic reform of the pension system in France that will bring together French, European and Non-#EU citizens alongside with professional organisations.

Read more in the link in bio!

The recently published #IPCC synthesis report made one thing crystal clear: the climate crisis is turning into a catastrophe at our doorstep. 

Are we doomed? Not yet, we believe. But we need to change our ways. Fast.

For this to happen, we believe that climate activism holds the key. What we envision is a kind of climate activism that builds, connects and helps people understand this emergency.

Climate activism canâ€™t be a replacement for well-written and forward-thinking laws. So, the only course of action political parties have is to embrace climate activism, work with it, become a platform for it. Together, we may still have a chance!

Why are women still underrepresented in politics? 

According to the UN, it will be another 130 years before women are equally represented in the highest positions of power, and just over 30% of MPs in EU national governments are women. 

Female politicians face more online abuse than their male counterparts, with one report finding that during the 2020 US presidential campaign, tweets about female candidates were more likely to be abusive than those aimed at their male counterparts. 

Thereâ€™s lots we can do to close the gender gap in politics: quotas, legislation combating cyber-violence, anti-harassment training, and better political education in schools.

We welcome the arrest warrant issued by the International Criminal Court (ICC) against Putin, even if it is  mainly a symbolic gesture! 

Still, this remains an important signal in the fight against war crimes and breaches of international law worldwide. However, in supporting it, Europe must clearly demonstrate that we are not merely using the ICC as a "political tool" to pursue our interests. 

We must not forget that many families and relatives of the victims of the wars in Syria, Afghanistan and Iraq are still hoping in vain for justice: international law only works if we apply it to all and unfortunately, there are still many countries, such as China, USA, Russia, and more that are not partners of the Rome Statutes establishing the ICC. 

This clearly shows that national, European and international institutions must be reformed in the long run to to be able to effectively prosecute and punish war crimes, while remaining independent from political spheres of influence. 

Together, we can create a new Common European Foreign and Security Policy and make Europe fairer for everyone!

The recent #IPCC confirms we are reaching the critical level of 1.5 degrees increase in temperature.

Action is needed now! 
According to the #IPCCReport â€œthere is a rapidly closing window of opportunity to secure a liveable and sustainable future for allâ€. At this rate, global warming is more likely than not to reach 1.5Â°C in the near future. The IPCC warns that, to limit global warming to 1.5Â°C, we need rapid, deep and in most cases immediate greenhouse gas emissions reductions in ALL sectors THIS DECADE.

Climate change is already at the point where it is definitely having broad negative effects on people and ecosystems. 

This report is effectively our final warning. For the rapid change that is required, we need political commitment. We need our leaders to set more ambitious targets to achieve net zero emissions by 2040, to break the barriers that obstruct the necessary increase in adaptation and mitigation financing, to prioritise equity, climate justice and social justice, and to protect and make our most vulnerable communities more resilient.

ğŸš¨Our current approach to human trafficking isn't cutting it, and it's time for a change!

Did you know that more than 1.3 million people are trapped in modern slavery in the EU, and a staggering 71% of trafficking victims are women? This is a major issue that requires urgent attention.

Framing trafficking solely as a criminal justice matter isn't working. We need to shift our focus towards prevention and the rehabilitation of victims. 

The EU is currently reviewing its Directive on human trafficking, which presents a golden opportunity to adopt a bolder, more humane approach. At Volt, we firmly believe in a human rights-centred strategy that includes:

ğŸ¤ Providing healthcare and protection to victims without the need for legal cooperation
ğŸ›‚ Granting residence permits to victims identified in countries other than their own
ğŸšº Recognising that victims have different experiences, with women making up 71% of those trafficked, often for sexual exploitation.

Let's shift the focus to the victims, not the perpetrators.
Together, we can build a Europe that stands up for its people and respects their rights ğŸ™Œ more in the link in bio!

When will Bubatz become legal? ğŸ¥¦ This is a question many people in Germany have asked and after 16 years of conservative stalemate on German drug policy, the government is going ahead with making it legal for adults to grow and buy a certain amount of cannabis. But why is legalisation taking so long in Germany? Because this is in fact another issue that concerns the entire EU! ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º

In fact, cannabis is also regulated under European law and more specifically in:

ğŸ‘‰ Schengen Implementing Convention
Within the Schengen area, border controls no longer take place, which also means that drugs can cross the respective national borders uncontrolled. EU Member States are therefore obliged 
to take measures to prevent illicit trafficking of narcotics. 

ğŸ‘‰ European Criminal Law
Each Member State must take the necessary measures to ensure that the offering, offering for sale, distribution, sale and supply of drugs are punishable. 

â¡ï¸So what happens now? A war on drugs has not and will not work. We believe we should stop looking at this and other issues through a national lens and start discussing them using a European approach. In this light, what is happening in Germany is a good step forward and we hope it will lead to a broader discussion across EU countries on decriminalising drug possession below a certain amount.

â“What is your position on this issue? Would you have thought that national drug policies are linked to EU law?

 #DecriminalizeCannabis #EULaw #EUPolitics
