#VoltersStories: in this series, Volters from across Europe will share their stories on why they joined our pan-European movement, and how this enriched their lives. The first personal story is told by Silvia Panini (Silvia Panini Volt):
â€It is always difficult to explain what Volt Europa is and how it differs from other political forces â€” perhaps because it is much more than just a traditional party.

ğŸ¤ Volt is a community.
Among Volt members there are many people like me but many of them are also quite different: there are those who still study and those who have a family, those who live in Italy and those who do not, and those who make political communication and expose themselves and those who work behind the scenes. But we all share the desire to change something in the political and social system in which we live. We have a vision, a dream, an ideaâš¡ and we bring our different experiences to the community to make it real.

ğŸ“– Volt is a school.
Given the great breadth of experience the volunteers' bring in, each Volter has a lot to teach and contribute to the community.
In Volt, all the activities that are usually carried out by professionals in large parties are realised by volunteers. Since I've been here, I've learned to speak in public, deal with public relations with journalists and politicians, and report on an election campaign.
ğŸ’œ And above all, I learned to deal with different people, different realities, and different worlds; to make the people around me stronger and more aware of their abilities; to synthesize different ideas.

â­ Volt is an opportunity.
It is the opportunity to regain confidence in the politics that is made by people, for people, without screaming or giving false hope, by being fear-mongering and winning votes, but with competence and a spirit of learning.â€

De Nederlandse regering maakt een wet om vluchtelingen in Nederland te spreiden, maar houdt eerlijke verdeling in de EU tegen. Staatssecretaris Van der Burg wilde de Dublinverordening weer op tafel te krijgen via geitenpaadjes in de wet. Waar veel experts al voor waarschuwden bleek te kloppen, toen hij vorige week werd teruggefloten door de rechter.
 
Volt heeft een Europees lange termijn plan. Geen geitenpaadjes in de wet, maar de crisis duurzaam oplossen met een akkoord over een gemeenschappelijk Europees Asiel- en Migratiepact. 

Totdat Europa met een oplossing komt, zal er nooit grip op migratie plaatsvinden. Mensen hebben recht op asiel en moeten daar ten alle tijden aanspraak op kunnen maken.

Today we celebrate the 5th year anniversary of Volt. In March 2017 the first pan-European party Volt was founded to unite the good forces of Europe to fight for democracy and oppose the rising far-right and the authoritarian leaders undermining it. 

In just 5 years we've been able to get more than 100 Volters elected around Europe. Let's celebrate this great accomplishment today. Let's celebrate this promising beginning of a better Europe. 

Join us today at 19:00 CET on Youtube to learn more about it and get to know Volters from all over Europe.

Volt opposes the mass surveillance plan called Chat Control

We are very concerned about the proposal by the European Commission . Their plan will do little to stop the spread of child sexual abuse material (CSAM) but will deeply cut into the civil rights of EU citizens. 

Thor Larholm, board member of Europa: â€œWe can solve crimes without having to implement backdoors that share our most intimate moments with criminals and undemocratic regimes. Any backdoor is a future security disaster.â€

The Commission seems to believe itâ€™s necessary to ask people for consent when it comes to website cookies but appears to think it is acceptable to spy on every single private conversation.

We plea for the European Parliament  to reject the Commissionâ€™s proposal and ask president von der Leyen to focus on effective ways to combat the spread of CSAM.

Rebekka Mueller, co-president of Volt Deutschland : â€œWe can all agree that fighting child abuse has to be a major priority. However, comprehensive surveillance technology monitoring private conversations without probable cause cannot be the answer.â€

Het kabinet voert ons plan uit: een afkoelperiode voor bewindslieden!

Een Kamermeerderheid hadden we al. Maar na een aangenomen motie moet je goed in de gaten houden of het kabinet er wel mee aan de slag gaat. Dat heeft minister Ollongren nu gedaan: de afkoelperiode komt erâ€¦ zie ook het stuk (op de voorpagina!) van @de_volkskrant van vandaag. We zullen het kabinet nog wel kritisch blijven volgen of en hoe de afkoelperiode gehandhaafd zal worden. 

De Europese anti-corruptiewaakhond GRECO deed in 2019 al de aanbeveling om in Nederland een afkoelperiode in te voeren om zo de politieke integriteit te versterken. Dit draagt bij aan het vertrouwen van burgers in de politiek. Om dezelfde reden willen we ook een lobbyregister dat inzicht geeft in contacten tussen bewindslieden en hoge ambtenaren met lobbyisten. Ook hier hebben we een meerderheid voor gekregen. Wordt vervolgd!

Volt stands strongly in solidarity with the people of Iran in their fight for freedom. For weeks now, the Iranian government has been using excessive force to repress protestors, who took to the streets following the death of Mahsa Amini at the hands of the Iranian religious police.

Since then, there are reports of dozens, if not hundreds more deaths as the authoritarian Iranian elite try to cling to power using violence. Recently, the murder of a 17-year-old freedom fighter, Nika Shakarami, sparked headlines around the world and fuelled the peopleâ€™s resistance.

To show our support to the protestors, we will be promoting the voice of the Iranian people on our channels in the coming weeks. In this first post, we asked two Iranian women to share their thoughts on the protests. We have hidden their names for the sake of their safety.

What are your feelings right now?

Person 1: â€œI am devastatedâ€¦â€
Person 2: â€œI have 2 different feelings at the same time: Iâ€™m so sad because of what is happening in Iran right now and during the last 43 years. On the other side, Iâ€™m so happy to see young people are amazingly brave, fighting for their basic rights and supporting each other. This generation is wonderful, no word can explain their bravery!

What is your hope for the future?

Person 1: â€œâ€¦to get rid of the Islamic Republic.â€
Person 2: â€œHistory of Iran is full of sad days, but nothing will remain foreverâ€¦it will change soon or late because the sun canâ€™t stay behind clouds always. We have hope and we will fight for our hope to come true!â€

What do you think the EU / world can do to help you?

Person 1: â€œI expect them to stop tolerating the Islamic Republic. Take an action such as to summon the Islamic republic ambassadors, etc.â€
Person 2: â€œAll of the sanctions till now, we're just against people and made their life harder though the government were free and abusing these sanctions to torture people more. The world has to forget the benefits of oil business with the corrupted government of Iran and stay with the people even if it has no economic benefits for them!â€

Thanks to talented Iranian artist Mana Neyestani for letting us use his illustration: https://www.instagram.com/neyestanimana/

#VoicesOfIran

Volt starts internal #HeForShe campaign

#HeForShe is a solidarity campaign originally started by UN Women to advance gender equality in our societies. The idea of #HeForShe is that fighting the inequality between genders canâ€™t just be the responsibility of the discriminated but has to be driven by men, too. 

Our goal as Volt Europa is to change our continent for the better. But in order to improve Europe ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º, we constantly have to work on ourselves and embody the change we want to see in our societies. 

And letâ€™s be frank, gender inequality exists almost everywhere and sadly within our organisation, too. For this reason a group of Volters - under the patronage of our co-president Francesca Romana D'Antuono - found together with the goal to combat this deficit. 

Last Friday was the official launch of the #HeForShe campaign within Volt with an event for all Volters, aiming at presenting the initiative and gathering further support. Additional activities and events are already planned in order to create extra awareness for the topic and the initiative and to put in place concrete actions. 

We are aware of the fact that we are just at the beginning of our journey. This is why in our strive for more gender equality, we seek support and help of external partners and experts. 

We will keep you posted on our future endeavours and events.

Passover - Hope in uncertain times

This Friday, Jews around the world are starting to celebrate Passover, which commemorates the Exodus from Egypt. "From slavery to freedom" is one of the most important concepts that is related to this holiday, which is celebrated with a festive meal together with family and friends.

A global pandemic, a global climate crisis and the ongoing war in Ukraine makes our current outlook seem particularly grim. We don't need to imagine what it must feel like to flee from tyranny, we are very aware of it. Either through our own experiences or those of loved ones, friends, or strangers whose stories have reached our hearts. It is easy to lose hope. But the bitter sweetness of Passover,expressed by some of the dishes on the festive table, Maror ( bitter herbs) and Charoset (sweet date + nut jam), also presents us with another concept: perseverance of hope in uncertain times.

Standing up for democracy comes at a cost

This week, under orders from Putin, the Russian Federation halted gas supplies to ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º member states Poland and Bulgaria. This development launches the Russia and EU energy conflict into a new stage, as the Kremlin weaponizes its energy leverage. 

(Even though it was to be expected,) this marks a point in which we need to stick together and show solidarity amongst ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º member states. In fact, in spite of other governments not complying with the request of making their payments in Russian Rubles, Poland and Bulgaria have been targeted by Putinâ€™s regime in an effort to divide the ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º. These countries have not only been the entryway for many fleeing the violence of war but are also former satellite states of the Soviet Union. They have since won their independence and were able to build democracies after years of war and dictatorship âœŠ As such, the hardships that Russia is now imposing show an escalation in the war. 

US President Joe Biden said that â€œdefending democracy and liberty is never without cost.â€ This is the cost for Europe: blackmail through energy supplies and threats by Putin and his cronies. Purchasing gas from Russian suppliers is fuelling a war, which according to the UN, has killed at least 2,729 civilians so far, of which 186 are children, as reported by Ukraineâ€™s ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ prosecutorâ€™s office. 

Volt Europa calls for all European governments to accelerate the green transition ğŸŒ± and step away from fossil fuels, which are a resource for the Russian army to advance their aggression in Ukraine. 

Governments across Europe need to prepare for energy rationing, rely ever more on sustainable resources, and protect citizens and businesses from the consequences of potential energy supply shortages. We are all together in this. The ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º has to share energy resources between its member states and we have to stand by each other. 

Now is the time for extraordinary political courage in defense of democracy and freedom âœŠ that has allowed Europeans to prosper, grow and innovate over the last decades. This is the time to be steadfast in our resolution to stand with Ukrainians ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ in our common fight against tyranny.

Volt Europa entered the European Parliament with the ambition to reform the EU. The reform of the European elections is the first step towards this goal! Below are five reasons why we need this reform:

  1. We need true European democracy! Currently, there are 27 national rules determining the outcome of the European elections. There is no European debate, no European accountability, no European democracy! Giving Europeans a truly European vote will be a step towards alleviating the democratic deficit of the EU.

  2. Each vote needs to matter! Electoral thresholds exclude the voices of millions of people. Moreover, it goes against the principle of the equality of the vote!

  3. Make EU politics younger! Every 18-year-old European can now run for the European elections. This was not the case before! By giving the option to 16-year-olds to vote for younger politicians, European politics will become younger!

  4. European politics need to become innovative and competitive. Allowing new political ideas to enter the political debate and decision-making makes politics more diverse and more innovative!

  5. Make voting easy! Make sure that every European citizen, no matter if imprisoned, or far from home, or not there on election day, homeless, or one with a handicap can vote!

#EuropeanParliament, #europeanelections, #EUreform, #europeanunion

This Holocaust Remembrance Day, we remember all the victims of the Shoa - victims of Antisemitism, hate, prejudice, and racism. We take a long, hard look at our history here in Europe, and at how societies were able to turn upon each other so viciously.

The planned, industrially executed destruction of the European Jewry by Nazi Germany is unique in history - but it hasnâ€™t been the last time we witnessed genocide since. We tend to view that era as though Fascism just happened upon peaceful people and turned them into monsters. Yet, we fail to see that the very same societies that allowed the Shoa to happen, again dabble in anti-democratic rhetoric, ostracize minorities, allow vicious antisemitism and racism of all kinds to spread their venom, and stay silent in the face of heinous atrocities against civilians, such as happened in Bucha, Ukraine - and many other places around the world.

This Yom Hashoa, the Day of Holocaust Remembrance, is another chance for us to turn from apathy to action!

Tough times require tough decisions. Now, Europe needs to act as a single bloc. Yet the interests of individual countries can block united action. The veto was originally designed to protect minority rights of small member states, but in practice erodes the Union's ability to act for the common good of all Europeans.

For 15 years, the EU has not implemented constitutional reforms. Today, European citizens are clear: abolish the veto and allow the EU to take responsibility for its position in global decision-making. The Conference on the Future of Europe, a democratic innovation, has allowed a randomly selected group of citizens from all over Europe to come up with ideas to change the EU. Getting rid of the veto is one of the 49 ideas they came up with. To answer to what citizens want, to make the EU more democratic, and to enable the EU to act, this out-dated form of decision-making needs to be abolished. 

5 years ago, one of our promises was to abolish the veto. Join us! Sign the petition and open letter, addressed towards the leaders involved in the Conference, advocating for change and a clear follow up. 

Only a united Europe can solve the challenges of the 21st century. 

Get involved: https://noveto.eu/?utm_source=VoltEuropa&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=CotFoE

#NoVeto, #CotFoE  #EuropeanUnion

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Environmental Education â€“ Education is a force for fostering social mobility and inclusion, as well as the foundation to unite people in a vibrant and dynamic democracy. Education is also a way to encourage and innovate urban development programmes that fulfil specific environmental requirements, intending to make cities greener. Greener cities actively contribute to reducing the impacts of climate change and reducing emissions, such as COâ‚‚ and ozone, which negatively affect citizens' health. Investing in greener cities contributes to the sustainable development of communities which has long-term economic and social benefits. 

Participants of the Conference on the Future of Europe call for minimum standards to ensure buildings and spaces are as green as possible. â€Greenâ€, here, refers to the use of renewable energy sources, reduced energy consumption, low levels of COâ‚‚ emissions and the inclusion of plants in architectural projects. 

A lack of coordination between member states is hindering the effectiveness of existing campaigns and slowing efforts to fight the global challenge that is climate change. Therefore, Volt welcomes the innovative idea of providing training campaigns, disseminated across all available media channels and a new dedicated information portal, in which consistent information is communicated to citizens about the impact of daily actions such as their chosen means of transportation and waste treatment.

Last month, Volt Nederland proposed in the Dutch parliament a policy that would ensure free meals at schools for children. Because of the soaring inflation, many families have trouble affording even basic necessities like food for three meals a day. 

Voltâ€™s proposal was supported by parliament and adopted by the government. 100 million euros have been allocated to provide free meals for schools across The Netherlands, ensuring that every child has the energy to pay attention to school. 

Measures like this should be adopted across Europe. Everywhere people are struggling to pay the bills. Governments must protect the most vulnerable of us, and ensure that no child goes hungry this winter. By providing free meals at schools, governments can ease the burden on families, while simultaneously giving children equal access to healthy diets.

Congratulations Volt Nederland and Laurens Dassen for this successful proposal!

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Youth unemployment is a challenge. Are we addressing it?
Each country has a different job market with regulations that take into account history, culture and economic paradigm.

It is clear that different approaches produce different outcomes and countries like the Czech Republic ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¿ (7.9%) or Germany ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª (5.7%) set an example of integration of the youth workforce in the labour market.

Action has been taken by the European Union through the 2021-2027 budget and the Next Generation funds, which will transform our societies helped by other programs such as the Youth Employment Support Package

Each country has specific issues that cause difficulties in reducing youth unemployment and targeting the key areas that support integration in the labour market, innovation in education guaranteeing the acquisition of the necessary skills and promotion of entrepreneurship to bring to life new ideas is the way of giving our youth the future they deserve.

What are our next steps?

The Conference on the Future of Europe offered relevant insights that can be adopted by all Member States in order to keep improving the labour system as collective machinery that fuels our future.

3 steps in the right direction are:

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º Harmonisation of all different education programs in the EU with acceptance of the national content.

ğŸ—£ï¸ Practising soft skills such as encouraging dialogue, critical thinking, self-study and focusing on results, among others, should be integrated into the curriculum in schools.

ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» Establishing plans that would activate in crisis scenarios, like a pandemic or war, that deploy in a flexible way to minimise the impact on our youngstersâ€™ studies, vocational training and mental wellbeing.

Weâ€™re setting the path; our youth will be travelling it.

Last week we kicked off the #VoicesOfIran campaign, lending our channels to Iranians to amplify their voices. Democracy dies in darkness but may be born in light. So, we call on you to talk to Iranians in your network - see what you can do to help them speak up safely!

All Iranian protesters want to get basic rights: The right to freedom in things like religion, information, and clothing. To have a voice in the politics of your country. To equality between women and men. These are the same values we fight to protect as a European party, and that we wish to promote around the globe. 

This time, we spoke to an Iranian woman, who has recently come to Europe for research and study.

What do you think the EU/world can do to help the women of Iran?
The following proposals would help us in our struggle:

#1 Non-recognition of Iranian ambassadors and government anymore to support people's protest
#2 Targeted Sanctions of Iran: Blocking assets and deporting influential government officials from Europe and other countries. This does more than full economic sanctions on Iran, which would put pressure on the Iranian people
#3 Grant Iranian refugees in the EU the same status and access as Ukrainian refugees
#4 Improving conditions and providing better facilities for getting a resident permit for all Iranians who want to live outside the country

What is your hope for the future of Iran?
I hope Iran can be free and the protest will finally help overcome the current constraints. We want basic rights like freedom of speech and thought, freedom of religion, and especially freedom for women to wear what they want, permission to go to another country, to study, to work, and to live.

What are your feelings right now?
Although I am fearful about the uncertainty of the future, now, I want to be our voice, to support the people of my country to get them the rights that we deserve. What I deeply want is that the killing and imprisonment of innocent people will stop as soon as possible to end the terror.

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Renewable Energy Now â€“ We all know that the use of combustible fuels creates greenhouse gasses and that EU member states must reduce this type of energy to comply with the Paris Agreement. Since we cannot stop COâ‚‚ emissions immediately, we need to take short- and long-term measures. Either way, we need to transition towards a sustainable society. 

As suggested during the Conference on the Future of Europe, we must focus on the possibilities of generating energy through hydrogen and nuclear sources. The best solution would be to produce energy without COâ‚‚. Wind energy should be used for the production of green hydrogen and the EU should invest more in developing long-term renewable energy storage. 

Achieving decarbonisation is the most important objective for Volt. Nuclear energy is an essential energy source in decarbonisation for the EU and the whole world. As most trajectories compatible with a 1.5Â°C threshold rely on nuclear energy according to the latest IPCC report, nuclear energy will continue to play an essential role in climate change mitigation in the years to come. Thus, nuclear energy infrastructure investments are necessary for efficiency, safety, and innovation.

Den 23. juni vil resultaterne af Konferencen om Europas Fremtid blive prÃ¦senteret. I de kommende dage vil vi se nÃ¦rmere pÃ¥ tre af de forslag, som deltagerne har diskuteret. 
 
HÃ¥rde tider krÃ¦ver hÃ¥rde beslutninger. Nu er Europa nÃ¸dt til at handle som en samlet blok. Men de enkelte landes interesser kan blokere for en fÃ¦lles indsats. Vetoretten blev oprindeligt udformet for at beskytte smÃ¥ medlemsstaters mindretalsrettigheder, men i praksis undergraver den EU's evne til at handle til gavn for alle europÃ¦ere.
 
I 15 Ã¥r har EU ikke gennemfÃ¸rt forfatningsmÃ¦ssige reformer. I dag er de europÃ¦iske borgere klar i mÃ¦let: afskaf vetoretten, og lad EU tage ansvar for sin position i den globale beslutningstagning. Konferencen om Europas Fremtid, som er en demokratisk nyskabelse, har givet en tilfÃ¦ldigt udvalgt gruppe af borgere fra hele Europa mulighed for at komme med idÃ©er til at Ã¦ndre EU. Afskaffelse af vetoretten er en af de 49 idÃ©er, som de kom med. For at imÃ¸dekomme borgernes Ã¸nsker, for at gÃ¸re EU mere demokratisk og for at sÃ¦tte EU i stand til at handle, skal denne forÃ¦ldede form for beslutningstagning afskaffes. #NoVeto
 
For 5 Ã¥r siden var et af Volts lÃ¸fter at afskaffe vetoret. Slut dig til os! Skriv under pÃ¥ underskriftsindsamlingen og det Ã¥bne brev, der er rettet til de ledere, der deltog i konferencen, og som gÃ¥r ind for forandring og en klar opfÃ¸lgning. 
 
Kun et forenet Europa kan lÃ¸se udfordringerne i det 21. Ã¥rhundrede. 
 
Bliv involveret: https://noveto.eu/.
ENGLISH
On the 23rd of June, the results of The Conference on the Future of Europe will be presented. In the upcoming days, we will take a sharper look at three of the proposals discussed by participants. 
 
Tough times require tough decisions. Now, Europe needs to act as a single bloc. Yet the interests of individual countries can block united action. The veto was originally designed to protect minority rights of small member states, but in practice erodes the Union's ability to act for the common good of all Europeans.
 
For 15 years, the EU has not implemented constitutional reforms. Today, European citizens are clear: abolish the veto and allow the EU to take responsibility for its position in global decision-making. The Conference on the Future of Europe, a democratic innovation, has allowed a randomly selected group of citizens from all over Europe to come up with ideas to change the EU. Getting rid of the veto is one of the 49 ideas they came up with. To answer to what citizens want, to make the EU more democratic, and to enable the EU to act, this outdated form of decision-making needs to be abolished. #NoVeto
 
5 years ago, one of Voltâ€™s promises was to abolish the veto. Join us! Sign the petition and open letter, addressed to the leaders involved in the Conference, advocating for change and a clear follow-up. 
 
Only a united Europe can solve the challenges of the 21st century.

Vores arbejdsmarked Ã¦ndrer sig og vores arbejdsmarkedsparter skal flytte med sÃ¥ vi har et fair og fleksibelt arbejdsmarked i Europa! Det krÃ¦ver ogsÃ¥ at vores fagforeninger i Danmark reflekterer over, hvordan vi kan organisere os bedre til at imÃ¸dekomme fremtidens arbejdsmarked i den post-industrielle verden.

DesvÃ¦rre ser vi bÃ¥de et fald i fagforeningsmedlemskab og en stigende problemer i form af lave lÃ¸nninger og dÃ¥rlige arbejdsforhold. Det rammer de mest udsatte grupper pÃ¥ arbejdsmarkedet hÃ¥rdest: ufaglÃ¦rte, kvinder og internationale arbejdere.

DIrektivet siger at medlemslande skal arbejde pÃ¥ fÃ¸lgende: 

 - At etablere procedurer for tilstrÃ¦kkeligheden ved mindstelÃ¸n
 - At promovere kollektive forhandlinger ved lÃ¸nfastsÃ¦ttelse

Vores danske MEPere mener dog at direktivet truer den danske model - selvom kollektiv overenskomst bliver fremhÃ¦vet som den gyldne standard!

ENGLISH

Time to talk about the Future of work!

Our labour market is changing and our social partners must move with it so that we have a fair and flexible labour market in Europe!
It also requires our trade unions in Denmark to reflect on how we can better organise ourselves to meet the future labour market of the post-industrial world.

Unfortunately, we are seeing both a decline in union membership and a growing problem of low pay and poor working conditions. This hits the most vulnerable groups in the labour market hardest: unskilled workers, women and international workers.

Yesterday, the Minimum Wage Directive was implemented and Volt welcomes it ! The directive asks member states to work on the following: 

 - To establish procedures for the adequacy of minimum wages
 - To promote collective bargaining in wage setting
 - To strengthen wage protection EITHER through minimum wages or collective agreements.

However, our Danish MEPs believe that the directive threatens the Danish model - even though collective bargaining is highlighted as the golden standard!

Today, many European citizens have a very insecure relationship with the labour market as they have neither access to collective agreements nor minimum wages. 
We must work to change this and that is what the Minimum Wage Directive does!

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Gender equality is a fundamental right intrinsically linked to sustainable development. In the current state of our societies, womenâ€™s rights are being constantly threatened. 

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º The report issued during Panel 1 â€œStronger economy, social justice and jobs/education, culture youth and sport/digitalâ€ of the Conference of the Future of Europe is clear: 

The EU Gender Equality Strategy should be a priority; civil rights and gender equality should be achieved at the European level in all countries *without exception*. 

âŒ›ï¸ According to the World Economic Forumâ€™s Global Gender Gap Report (GGGR), only 68% of the gender gap is closed in 2022. The GGGR further estimates that gender parity will not be reached before 132 years. 

Europe has the second-highest level of gender parity currently standing at 76,6% yet important disparities can not be unseen. 

Within the EU, a difference of almost 20 percentage points between the member states is distinguishable. Measures are urgently needed to close this gender gap! 

To achieve gender equality, Volt Europa is committed to the following: 

â€¢ Make reporting on gender representation mandatory at all levels of government
â€¢ Require all mid-sized to large companies to disclose and report on gender balance and the gender pay gap. 
â€¢ Enable equal paid maternity and paternity leave

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: Reducing Waste â€“ We exploit, produce value, and then throw it away. Our existing economic model operates in this manner, and it is completely unsustainable. It is unjust to people who are harmed by brutal working conditions or polluted living environments. It's also unjust to future generations, who won't be able to use the resources we're squandering.

We must move toward a circular economy, as called for by participants at the Conference on the Future of Europe, with financial incentives for those who comply aimed at both corporations and citizens. Participants also urged that the EU go above and beyond to allow customers to keep products for extended periods. Our disposable, single-use society cannot be sustained. Manufacturers should be forced to indicate their products' projected lifespan. In exchange, the EU should provide information on how to re-use and repair things, such as through the internet and education.

Lukas Grahams samarbejde med Vestas om at afholde en koncert ved hjÃ¦lp af batterier opladet af vindkraft er genialt og forhÃ¥bentligt ikke sidste gang vi ser dette!

ENGLISH 
Making art a green pleasure!

Now, let's discuss how we can stop using fossil fuels all together. 

Danish artist Lukas Graham worked with Danish wind energy company Vestas to host a concert using batteries charged by wind power.

Battery technology is necessary to ensure that the solar and wind adventures that governments are investing in can work. 
But right now, gas, coal and oil are the fossil fuels that not only support the weather dependent energy sources, they're also the e energy sources we want to eliminate from our energy mix. 

We find it dangerously insufficient to only say what we want to remove without stating how we will replace it. 

Battery technology, like hydrogen, is still in its infancy and we need to have a real energy conversation about how we actually remove fossils from our energy mix.

Op bezoek in MoldaviÃ« ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡© 

Dit land met ongeveer 2,5 miljoen inwoners is momenteel in hoog tempo de nodige veranderingen aan het doorvoeren. Van een corrupte staat met een sterke focus op Rusland naar een rechtsstaat die kandidaat lid van de Europese Unie wil worden. 

Slechts 6 jaar geleden werd in MoldaviÃ« de Partij voor Actie en Solidariteit (PAS) opgericht door Maia Sandu. Doel: het land bevrijden van de verstikkende deken van corruptie en eigenbelang. In 2019 deed de partij voor het eerst mee aan de Parlementsverkiezingen, maar in 2021 won de partij de verkiezingen met een meerderheid. Hervormingen in het rechtssysteem, aanpakken van corruptie, persvrijheid (dit jaar 49 plekken gestegen in de lijst van @rsfinternational ğŸ’ª), beter investeringsklimaat, kansen voor jonge MoldaviÃ«rs en opvang van OekraÃ¯ense vluchtelingen staan, naast vele andere onderwerpen, hoog op de agenda. 

Te midden van de oorlog in OekraÃ¯ne, enorme inflatie (27%), een braindrain en Russische propaganda, is een nieuwe generatie politici onder leiding van de indrukwekkende president @maia.sandu bezig om het land klaar te stomen voor de 21ste eeuw. Een belangrijk onderdeel daarvan is de aanvraag van het kandidaat lidmaatschap van de Europese Unie (waar Volt ze in steunt). 

Ontzettend bijzonder om te zien met hoeveel idealisme, passie, energie en wilskracht deze groep zich inzet om echte en structurele veranderingen voor elkaar te boxen! Wij moeten ze daarin steunen door ze het perspectief op die Europese toekomst te geven. 

Daarnaast had ik het geluk om kort bij te praten met @mihaelasiritanu over de ontwikkelingen van @voltromania en de weg naar de Europese verkiezingen van 2024! ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º

#ConferenceOnTheFutureOfEurope: How many languages have you learned in your life?ğŸ§ Most people would certainly mention their mother tongue and maybe additionally English.

Languages open up many opportunities and new perspectives. Especially in the European job market, the ability to speak several languages fluently is often demanded. 

However, languages also play a major role in connecting with people from other backgrounds, thus forming shared experiences and European identity. Therefore, the opportunities to learn languages should be distributed fairly and prioritized equally within the European Union.ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º

Many people do not know of the existence of exchange programmes such as â€œErasmusâ€ for apprentices. In addition, many people cannot afford voluntary student exchanges at school. 

Therefore, we share the opinion of the Conference on the Future of Europe, that the European Union needs to empower people to engage with their European identity. We recommend promoting multilingualism from an early age. Reading the recommendations of the Conference of the Future of Europe often seems like reading Volt policies. We in Denmark can certainly identify with many of the desires expressed at the Conference of the Future of Europe.

The Conference wants lifelong learning and digitalisation. More people should be introduced to digitalisation while youths should have more training opportunities, better guidance and internship opportunities.

The Conference of the Future of Europe calls for work-life balance. For example that companies should have daycare facilities for staff with children and that workplaces in general should be more digital and flexible. Italyâ€™s parliamentary elections have signalled a shift to the right not only for Italy itself but also for Europe. An alliance between the â€Brothers of Italyâ€, Lega, and Forza Italia â€“ led by right-wing agitators #Meloni and #Salvini, as well as media magnate, ex-PM, and kingmaker #Berlusconi â€“ has gained 44% of the vote in Europeâ€™s third-largest economy.

Meloni used the slogan â€defend Italyâ€ in her campaign. Her vision for society is illustrated by the following quote: â€Yes to the natural family. No to the LGTB lobbies. Yes to sexual identity. No to gender ideology. â€¦ Yes to the sovereignty of the peoples. No to Brussels bureaucrats.â€ 

Ideologies based on nationalism, racism, and the denial of othersâ€™ freedom and equality, lead only to our darkest selves. We witnessed the damage they can inflict during World War II and see what damage it inflicts today under Putinâ€™s Russia. Italyâ€™s choice to go down this path again, for the first time since Mussolini, is a symptom of people's real fears in todayâ€™s uncertain times. 

The #energy crisis exacerbates the skyrocketing #inflation, and Europe faces a war on its borders on a scale not seen since the 1940s. Climate change is driving more and more #migrants from Africa to Europe, the prospect of which makes people afraid because the current processing of migrants leaves much to be desired. 

This is why Volt believes that, contrary to what the Brothers of Italy pose, more Europe is the answer, not less. The problems of today are too big, too complex, and too borderless to deal with alone.

Italy receives 190 billion euros from Brussels under the European Recovery Plan (the most of any EU country), which its economy needs to modernize and protect people from inflation. Saying â€œno to Brussels bureaucratsâ€ does not increase sovereignty, it simply decreases economic resilience

For everyone convinced that our future is European and wants to actively contribute to a better society: Join Volt! If not you, then who? If not now, when? -> https://www.volteuropa.org/

2023 Cypriot presidential election
On Sunday the candidate from New Wave || Volt Cyprus - The Other Cyprus Constantinos Christofides got 6.326 (1,6%) of the votes and finished 6th (out of 14). Back to school! ğŸ™Œ

Vandaag gaf ik een gastles op de Vinse school in Amsterdam en mocht ik de leerlingen uit de brede brugklas helpen bij hun debat over veiligheid en criminaliteit. We spraken over het belang van inhoudelijke voorbereiding, emotie, respect, voorbeelden en het gebruik van humor, oftewel ingrediÃ«nten om goed te kunnen debatteren. 

De Vinse is school is een bijzondere school! De school is kleinschalig, leerlingen van mavo, havo en vwo zitten er bij elkaar in brede brugklassen, en docenten krijgen er de ruimte om hun eigen onderwijs vorm te geven. Ontzettend leuk om de energie van de middelbare school weer te ervaren. En inspirerend om te zien hoe bevlogen alle leerlingen meededen in het debat.

In het Nederlandse onderwijs moet meer ruimte zijn voor scholen om zelf hun onderwijs vorm te geven. We moeten minder van bovenaf opleggen en meer vertrouwen hebben in docenten en leerlingen zelf. Net als in Finland waar de de Vinse school laat zich door laat inspireren!

Jaren geleden kwam Rik vol enthousiasme mijn studentenkamer op gestormd om te vragen of ik meeging naar een concert van UB40. Er zou een grote groep gaan en dat mocht ik volgens hem echt niet missen.

A project by Forum for International Cooperation (FIC) The rapidly evolving phenomenon of cyberbullying - bullying through social media, messaging platforms, gaming platforms etc - is a serious problem.  33 percent of youth across the globe experience bullying online, and European countries where children are the most at risk for online sexual exploitation and harmful material include Denmark, Finland, the Netherlands, and Norway. But what can be done to stop it, and what are the best practises? In dialogue with young people across the EU, FIC carried out a project aimed at identity best practises. Curious to know more? Join us for a dialogue on this alarming issue.

3 December 

Throughout December, we're sharing the political roadmap we ran on in 2019, when we stood for the European Parliament for the first time!
We want to run for the European Parliament in 2024 and that requires 71,000 voter declarations from all of your - will you help us get there?

Today, our December calendar is about inclusion in democratic processes!

We need better access to public services - in Denmark, this means reforming the unemployment benefit system, but we also need EU funds to be more accessible to citizens in Europe.

We aslo need better digital administration in the EU & Denmark should take a leading role! We have both good and bad experiences and these shouldb e shared with the rest of Europe!

Finally, we will remove the barriers to voting European Parliament.
We want to make it easy to register your residence digitally in an EU country and we want to strengthen the digital possibilities to vote. 

We think big and we want you to join us! Join our movement and give us your voter declaration today! www.voltdanmark.org/en/vaelgererklaering

Vi i Volt mener, at alle mennesker har lov til at bestemme hvordan livet skal ende. 

Derfor stÃ¸tter vi passiv dÃ¸dshjÃ¦lp og assisteret dÃ¸dshjÃ¦lp, for dem der har konstante og ubÃ¦rlige fysiske og/eller mentale smerter. 

LÃ¦gens rolle skal udelukkende vÃ¦re at udlevere det dÃ¸delige medikament og vi foreslÃ¥r at der oprettes en komitÃ©, der gennemgÃ¥r alle sager af assisteret dÃ¸dshjÃ¦lp.

ENGLISH

The Ethical Council in Denmark has today announced that they do not support active euthanasia.

We in Volt believe that all people have the right to decide how their lives should end. 

Therefore, we support passive euthanasia and assisted suicide for those in constant and unbearable physical and/or mental pain. 

The doctor's role should be solely to administer the lethal drug and we propose that a committee be established to review all assisted suicide cases. 

The committee should be composed of at least one medical expert, an ethicist and a legal expert. 

The most important thing is the dignity of a human being.

ENGLISH

Volt wants to unleash Europe's economic potential and bring about an economic rebirth! How, you ask?

The war in Ukraine is taking its toll and we must not let fear of economic insecurity stop us from supporting Ukraine's fight for freedom or backing its citizens' need for security.

Instead, we must actively work to ensure that our economic future is fair, just and sustainable and that we reduce inequalities between EU economies.

This requires us to look at our labour market, our economy

The future of work will not resemble the 20th century industrial way of working, so the challenge will be to ensure the living conditions and standards that we have found work and make sense, while enhancing the opportunity for innovation and development. This will require more cooperation at several levels, politicians, trade unions, the self-employed and citizens.

In this yearâ€™s State of the European Union (SOTEU 2022), the president of the European Commission, Ms von der Leyen, attempted to bring European institutions into peopleâ€™s everyday lives. Her message was clear: With the pandemic, the devastating climate impact on Europe, the war on Ukraine and subsequent migration streams, the energy crisis, and the rising inflation, Europe has to stand together.

Ursula von der Leyen did not, however, specify what this treaty reform process should focus on.
At Volt we say: letâ€™s start with what citizens have clearly stated matters to them at the Conference on the Future of Europe. For this reason, we ask for the end of the EU Council veto and for decision-making via a qualified majority, to vote on those things that matter to us all.

These should be the first steps toward a common, democratic and transparent European governance. The EU should become a true parliamentary democracy, where a Prime Minister, elected by the European Parliament, leads a federal cabinet of ministers and guides the day-to-day policy work of the Union. The establishment of a true European government, which is currently lacking, is a necessary step towards the creation and application of effective, common European policies.

Volt wants sustainable agriculture in all of Europe. We believe a European wide CO2 tax including on agriculture and a reform of the Common Agricultural Policy is an important step in this transformation. Furthermore, we want to phase out subsidies for all agricultural practices that degrade soil, cause erosion or load water bodies with harmful chemicals. Subsidies must be directed toward any agricultural practices that improve topsoil, capture GHGs, protect water bodies, promote biodiversity, and stop or reverse erosion.

To accomplish all of this Volt is sharing best practices across the continent, so we can move all of Europe forward in the green transition.

ENGLISH

EU - a community of values.

The Volt was born out of a European crisis - at a time of mistrust in common endeavour. 

Volt delivers a message of hope, boldness and solidarity, offering all European citizens a new European vision: one that embraces our common ambitions and addresses our shortcomings. 

We believe in a Europe that balances the freedoms of its single market with strengthened social protection and inclusion: where businesses and labour can move anywhere, and where this flexibility is not detrimental to workers. 

We support a Europe where solidarity means supporting each other and accepting shared responsibility for our common future. Where we actively support the development of our poorer regions and raise their living standards, and where EU citizens defend common interests. 

We believe in a Europe that works equally for all, not just for the privileged few.
A Europe where individuals and businesses contribute their fair share, wherever they may live in the Union. 

Our vision is a Europe that guarantees equal access to education, healthcare and social protection and employment opportunities for all. A Europe where citizens have the same rights and can rely on everyone contributing and benefiting equally from their involvement. 

Finally, we believe in a Europe that ensures full representation of all citizens. Our vision is of a Europe where a vibrant democratic community creates an open space for debate and allows all to participate and be recognised and respected in their diversity. 

One where citizens directly elect all their European representatives, hold them accountable and have their needs included in the decisions taken for all of us. 

We believe that this new Europe will strengthen our lives, give us opportunities to achieve individual ambitions while being part of a stronger society - a society of values.

The far-right Finns Party, who form part of Finland's coalition government, are the latest populist party to scrap their plans to leave the EU.

They're joining a long list of eurosceptic parties across Europe who have done the same, such as Marine Le Pen's National Rally in France, and the Five Star Movement in Italy.

While these parties remain eurosceptic, none of them want to leave the EU. Instead, they want to see more EU reforms.

Why have these parties scrapped their plans to leave the EU? Simple, it's not a vote winner. Brexit has highlighted to voters across Europe the chaos that would happen to their country if they chose to leave the EU.

The EU isn't perfect, but you don't fix it by leaving it.

ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡ºğŸƒ EU leaders gather February 9 & 10 to discuss the Unionâ€™s migration policy. 
Volt offers a solution to the ineffective and inhumane treatment of people entering Europe. Our approach would be better for migrants and for European citizens!

What needs to be fixed?
ğŸ—ºï¸ Distribution key to 27 EU countries: Letâ€™s tackle this with all member states!
ğŸ‘·Allow them to work from day 1: Letâ€™s not waste their potential!
ğŸšªDevelop a clear vision on regular migration: To ensure safe channels!

Read the full article here > https://medium.com/volt-europa/a-fortress-europe-will-not-hold-e9fb2c80cced 

The EUâ€™s current approach to asylum stems from the failed 1990 Dublin Regulation, which places most burden on countries of arrival. We need to revise this system to make sure all member states help with receiving migrants.

New arrivals are stopped from working, and have little contact with their host country. We should ease asylum seeker access to job markets. This carries benefits for all EU citizens, as it helps with our labour market shortages and quick integration, as we have seen with Ukrainian arrivals.

The EU should also create a clear vision on regular migration channels. Irregular migration is run by smugglers, dangerous for migrants, and makes it difficult to process new arrivals. Opening legal migration flows will unburden authorities and help keep people safe. 

Asylum seeker policy falls under EU legislation, and is something no member state can solve on their own. However, the EU has shown remarkably little progress in creating a system which shares the responsibility between member states, and which allows migrants to work and thrive in their host country.

Volt wants to unleash Europe's economic potential and bring about an economic rebirth! How, you ask?

The next personal story in the #VoltersStories series comes from Matthias Iannis Portelli: 

It is always a challenge to explain what Volt is in a few words and what makes it different from other political forces in Malta and in Europe, as it does not fit the traditional party definition. Volt is a community, an idea, and a way of life directed towards revitalising/rejuvenating our countries, Europe, and the world. 

It's directed towards unlocking Europe's potential and building a united and federal Europe, where everyone has the highest human rights, and environmental, socioeconomic, and technological standards that through its strong belief in greater subsidiarity can enrich Europe from the little hamlet I'm from of L-Andrijiet all the way to the biggest metropolitan areas.

I jokingly like comparing VoltEuropa to Bolt and Wolt, in the sense, just like how these services deliver food, Volt delivers democracy and sound solutions for the much-needed change through a Pan-Europeanist and Greater Subsidiarity approach; and it gives the much-needed jolt to the citizens of Europe whereby not restricting them through ideology and frivolities that limits party and individual movements but promotes and fosters independent thinking.

â€¨ğŸ¤ Volt is a community.

â€¨Volt truly brings people from different walks of life together. However, what fascinates me the most when it comes to Volt is, that among Volters, there are people from both sides of the spectrum, essentially from what is considered to be the conventional (centre-left to centre-right). 

The fact that Volt operates in this centrist manner from its prime ideology being based on reason and pragmatism, as to attempt to reconcile the left and right-wing under one single entity through its fundamental challenges that act in a way as its values, is extremely seductive for me, and something I believe makes us unique.

I personally joined Volt as I felt tired and politically homeless in Malta, not having a proper party, politicians, and political awareness. To me, it felt as if Malta had administrative-type politicians, that lacked vision and hunger to better the country and lives of its people, and this to me came as a relief when I stumbled upon Volt while scouring the internet at like 2am for a movement with a Pan-European solution.

Volt truly offers a rich community that has a strong desire to change something in the socio-political system we are all living in. Silvia Panini in her VoltersStories nicely put it: â€œWe have a vision, a dream, an ideaâš¡ and we bring our different experiences to the community to make it real.â€â€¨â€¨

ğŸ“– Volt is a way of life.â€¨

The wealth of skills the community possesses, and the fact that the great majority of its members are volunteers, gives way to all its members to learn new things. Either through Volt Academy, workshops, events, colleague interactions, or even through interacting with challenges. While Volt is made up of academics, activists, actors, artists, politicians, pilots, teachers, scholars, scientists, students, soldiers etc, the unconventional nature of Volt gives room for everyone to grow. 

Since I've been a member I've learned a great deal about politics, public speaking, lobbying, public relations, campaigning, and policy writing, as well as applying what I'm learning in class into actual practice and being more aware and educated when it comes to taboo topics like abortion. I would probably not have known much nor felt as comfortable as I do if it wasnâ€™t through VoltMalta in particular to Arnas and Alexia.

Above all, Volt's Progressivist Philosophy enshrouded in centrism provides the means to reconcile, and understand the different realities that shape our world. I personally think that Volt inspires and gives way to active citizenship, even if some might not agree with everything we believe in, it gives way to a discussion which is extremely healthy for politics and society. â€¨

With this, I'd like to end with: 
Volt is an opportunity to regain the much-needed confidence in politics, as for the most part, traditional politics has made people complacent which has resulted in political apathy that has as well created a loop of political mockery and fruitless arguments. It is an opportunity to change local and European politics.

Op zaterdag 8 juli stelde Volt BelgiÃ« zijn verkiezingsprogramma voor de federale verkiezingen van 2024 voor aan het geÃ¯nteresseerde publiek in het Via-Via CafÃ© in Mechelen.

Volt is een pan-Europese politieke beweging die actief is in 31 landen en zich richt op meer Europese samenwerking. De beweging is opgericht in 2017 en heeft sindsdien over heel Europa lokale afdelingen opgericht.

Volt streeft naar een meer democratisch, transparant en efficiÃ«nt Europa en pleit voor concrete actie in verschillende domeinen, zoals klimaatverandering, migratie, onderwijs en economie. De partij probeert de traditionele politieke scheidslijnen te overstijgen en zoekt naar oplossingen die de Europese samenwerking versterken. Volt neemt ook deel aan de verkiezingen in 2024.

Bij de presentatie van het verkiezingsprogramma lichtten Bram Vandeninden, Carlo Giudice, Johanna Dirlewanger-LÃ¼cke en Lucas Thijs vier van Volt's belangrijkste prioriteiten toe:

1.Investeringen in milieuvriendelijke en veerkrachtige infrastructuur, om transport-, energie- en communicatienetwerken te moderniseren en op lange termijn competitief te blijven.
2.Verbeteren van de mobiliteit en openbaar vervoer in BelgiÃ« door een beter en efficiÃ«nter management van het bestaande spoorwegnet en betaalbaarder maken van treinvervoer.
3.CreÃ«ren van een economie en samenleving waarin de burger centraal staat door onder andere een eerlijkere verdeling van belastingen. Hierbij worden lasten op arbeid verschoven naar lasten op vervuiling en activiteiten die de gezondheid schaden.
4. Pragmatische aanpak van de Energy Transition door een combinatie van kernenergie en hernieuwbare energie.

Volt applauds the European Parliamentâ€™s decision to reject granting a 2020 budget discharge to the EUâ€™s Border Guard Agency, Frontex.

The denial of discharge to #Frontex is a win for democracy after a series of internal fights. The Parliament finally sends a strong signal: no EU agency should be complicit in human rights violations. Volt, together with our MEP, has been calling for greater accountability and transparency of all EU agencies, and in particular Frontex.

Reports show that Frontex and its top management are responsible for numerous internal dysfunctions and ignored violations of human rights carried out on behalf of the national authorities. The sad reality is that thousands of refugees have been affected by Frontexâ€™ illegal practices. That is a failure of our democracy and of the upholding of the rule of law.

We advocate for a common and humane migration and asylum policy in the EU. It is also in desperate need of a transparent mechanism to hold institutions accountable. We call on the EU to take this evidence seriously and to address the Member Statesâ€™ active engagement in pushbacks at the external border.

Read more here: https://medium.com/volt-europa/frontex-violations-of-human-rights-1c6929bf24f5

Volt stands behind the women of Iran! Three words symbolise the revolution: Women, Life, Freedom. Jin, Jiyan, Azadi. These are the words which have inspired young and old, man and woman, urban and rural - everyone, to stand up against a regime which for too many years has ruled with violent oppression.

The fight for freedom, democracy, and equality, has battles in many different countries. The people of Iran inspire us to cherish the freedoms we have in Europe, and to do whatever we can to support them in their struggle.

As the revolution in Iran falls out of our news cycles in the West, it is important to keep attention on it. Spread the word, inform yourself, and speak up for those without a voice!

According to the #IPCCReport â€œthere is a rapidly closing window of opportunity to secure a liveable and sustainable future for allâ€. At this rate, global warming is more likely than not to reach 1.5Â°C in the near future. We need a real European High-Speed Rail Network! ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡ºğŸš„
European rail travel is a key component for a carbon-neutral future! To read more about our proposed solutions, read our opinion piece on our blog : 
https://medium.com/volt-europa/we-need-european-high-speed-rail-927c80f35660 

The birthplace of the train has neglected to improve its rail infrastructure. Whereas China has built the worldâ€™s largest integrated national high-speed rail network in 30 years, Europe only has a few loose pockets of HSR that are badly connected.

âœˆï¸ As a result, most Europeans fly to get to other places in the Union. This is bad in many regards, primarily because COâ‚‚ emissions per kilometre travelled are 6-8 times higher than that of rail. Without decarbonising, aviation could account for 22% of all global COâ‚‚ emissions by 2050.

Meanwhile, we live on a small, densely populated continent eminently suitable for fast rail connections. So what can be done? We offer a perspective on how it could be improved:

ğŸ“± Make it easier to book international trains in one integrated European app

ğŸ›« Make it less expensive by increasing taxes on aviation while reducing them on the rail, and using that money to invest in HSR

ğŸ‘® There should be an EU rail authority to oversee international connections to ensure proper transfer possibilities and fewer regional stops

ğŸš„ Invest significantly in European rail infrastructure, first by connecting the major HSR hubs (France, Spain, Italy), then by expanding the HSR network.

Improvement is very possible. The European Commission already set itself the goal to increase Europeâ€™s rail travel market share by double in 2030, and triple in 2050. Volt believes more urgency must be felt and pleads for an integral, European vision to connect the citizens of Europe in a fair and green way.

Volt calls on Danish trade unions to work together across borders to strengthen collective agreements across Europe!

Volt has a plan for the European job market!

Volt will invest in programmes that support the digital workforce in regions with high unemployment. We will make it easier to find jobs across Europe by expanding the European Employment Services (EURES) and we will increase public investment in lifelong learning programmes.

Een kleine groep wordt rijker, terwijl de rijen voor de voedselbank langer worden. 

We dringen al maanden bij het Kabinet aan op maatregelen die de koopkracht van de midden- en lage inkomensgroepen dit jaar nog zouden helpen. Maar de coalitie blokkeerde elke beweging ten gunste van die mensen waarvan we wisten dat ze zonder gerichte hulp in de diepe ellende terecht zouden komen.

We kunnen niet meer wachten. Het is nu tijd voor een inflatietoeslag via de zorgtoeslag, een Europese winstbelasting, voor een experiment met basisinkomen, voor een Europees afschalingsplan, voor gratis schoollunches & menstruatieproducten voor scholieren, en voor de overstap naar een groene samenleving. 

Want zoals we deze zomer zagen, met overstromingen, bosbranden en droogte: het klimaat kan zeker niet wachten.

Volt wants agricultural reform because we need a viable agriculture that does not destroy our nature. This requires reforming of the CAP, the Common Agricultural Policy in the EU.
This requires action at European level, which is why we are running for the European Parliament.

Our challenges are shared. We need shared policies and we need a pan-European party to achieve this! PLease support our run for Parliament.

"No matter where you put a tax, it ends up with the consumer. The tax always goes where the money is," said Liberal Party leader Jakob Ellemann-Jensen yesterday to his supporters in Kolding.
( https://nyheder.tv2.dk/live/politik/2023-10-02-ellemann-efter-stormfuldt-moede-med-baglandet-linjen-ligger-fast )

We need to stop polluting nature by changing our agricultural production. 

We need to move away from excessive animal production that releases nutrients that kill life in our oceans. 

We need to strengthen innovative ideas like vertical farming and that requires reforming agricultural subsidies.

Ga je de energiekosten betalen of doe je boodschappen? Steeds meer gezinnen moeten zichzelf deze vraag stellen, en 300.000 kinderen in Nederland glijden af in armoede. Gisteren kwam de Kamer terug van reces, de aanleiding was niet het gigantische koopkracht probleem, maar een minister die een partijpolitieke stunt uithaalde door tegen het regeerakkoord in te gaan.

Deze tijd vraagt om een kabinet dat zichtbaar is, perspectief biedt, en alles op alles zet om de mensen die het nodig hebben te helpen. Om het land bij elkaar te brengen, en ons voor te bereiden op een zware herfst en winter. Maar de afgelopen maanden heeft het kabinet keer op keer de nodige hulp uitgesteld. Gezegd dat er geen ruimte was, maar dat we ze kunnen vertrouwen om op Prinsjesdag met een plan te komen.

Ik hoop dat ze daad bij woord voegen, met een plan komen waar de hele Kamer achter kan staan, en waar we de mensen die nu financieel in de knel raken echt mee helpen: niet alleen voor 2023, maar al voor de komende herfst en winter, en de komende 5 jaar.

Making the EU better, more accessible and more transparent is one of our reasons for founding Volt.

But what can we do to achieve this vision?
Join us on Instagram LIVE on Europe Day, 9 May to discuss our vision for Europe with our MEP Damian Boeselager and our co-Presidents, Francesca Romana D'Antuono and Reinier Van Lanschot!

#VoltPoliticalPriorities: ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º Voltâ€™s primary goal is to make the European Union more democratic!

Willy Brandt, a German chancellor, once said â€œWir wollen mehr Demokratie wagenâ€ (we want to dare more democracy). This quote rings true today. The most voted-for policy issue at our GA concerned the topic of democracy in the EU. For this, reform is necessary. Instead of being a union of heads of state, the EU should be a union of citizens. 

ğŸ“In our vision, the European Parliament needs to have the right to initiate laws, like other parliaments in national spheres. To ensure that the European Parliament more accurately reflects the will of the European citizens, EP elections need to be Europeanised. Currently, EP elections too often function as midterm national elections. This must change - let the people vote for European parties with European candidates, on European issues. 

ğŸ¤The Spitzenkandidaten system, where leaders of parties run officially for President of the Commission, should gain more prominence. The citizens must decide who becomes the face of the EU, not the heads of state in a back-door deal. This will immediately grant the EU more democratic legitimacy, as the voice of the people will be honoured.

Volt wants to establish a true European government. One that answers to the European Parliament, and thus to the European people. One government that is capable of solving crises without worrying about vetoes from uncooperating states.

Steps are being taken in this regard. Treaty reform has been agendized by both Emmanuel Macron and Olaf Scholz. Germany lowered the legal age to vote in EP elections to 16 this week. We encourage these developments and cheer on leaders who see that the challenges of tomorrow can only be tackled through European cooperation supported by informed and engaged European demos.

If you want to commit yourself to create a more democratic European Union, join Volt today! Sign up to become a member on our website, and share our posts on your channels to help us grow!

#EU #Europe #FutureMadeInEurope #EuropeanParliament #EUreforms #Spitzenkandidaten #europeandemocracy

A European labour market where rights and opportunities are at the centre!

Volt went to the polls in 2019 on our pan-European election platform, the Amsterdam Declaration, and every day in December we shared posters from our political programme.

Today it's all about the labour market - it's the Danish government's big challenge and Volt has long talked about the solution: supporting a truly European labour market that provides opportunities, mobility and development across borders!

We do this by protecting all workers and ensuring that access to social, legal and medical services is guaranteed.

We will work to make Europe a centre of talent and innovation! It must be easy and attractive to get an expert visa, especially if you have already obtained a university degree from an EU country!

We support the EU Blue Card scheme, which attracts qualified colleagues from 3rd countries and we want to develop a Schengen visa for temporary foreign workers.

To avoid brain-drain, we will develop these solutions in cooperation with 3rd countries and involve all relevant stakeholders, such as employers and trade unions, in the policy-making process.

The European Parliament celebrated its 70th birthday yesterday!

The democratic body of the European Union was not always known as the European Parliament. It started as the Common Assembly of the European Coal and Steel Community. From these early beginnings, the European Parliament has evolved, adapted, and transformed into the body we know today.

Democracies and institutions are never static. Over time, the European Parliament has fought for more responsibilities and powers within the EU. This is necessary for democratic legitimacy. The EP, directly elected, represents the will of the people, and is the mechanism by which the executive Commission and Council are held accountable.

Roberta Metsola, the current EP President, highlighted the fact that the European Parliament is â€œthe only multilingual, multi-party, transnational parliament in the worldâ€. So many nationalities, cultural backgrounds, political ideologies, languages, and people are represented in this organ of democracy.

Voltâ€™s Member of the European Parliament, @damien.boeselager represents the voters of Volt in this complex system. Allying with the European Greens, he pleads for increased regulation of artificial intelligence, and for a more European approach to dealing with migration and border security. Just this last week a law negotiated by Damien was passed in the EP called RePower EU, this law gives more financial support to EU countries, their citizens and companies struggling with high energy prices. Yesterday, he addressed Parliament about the dangers of strongmen such as Hungaryâ€™s Viktor OrbÃ¡n and argued that the Commission should withhold funds from Hungary for their descent into autocracy and their support for Russia.

It is an honour that, in these 70 years, Volt has earned a place in the history of the European Parliament. For the elections in 2024, we aim to make a mark and expand our number of seats, so that we can make even more work of improving the Union and making it more cohesive and progressive!

#EuropeanParliament #Europe #EU #EP

Insgesamt waren 750 Volters aus ganz Europa angereist, damit war es die grÃ¶sste GA in der noch jungen Geschichte von Volt. ==================

Last weekend the GA of Volt Europa took place in Prague, Volt Switzerland participated with a small delegation. Between all the speeches and panels, there was also time for socialising with fellow Volters. Additionally, the Public Action on Saturday evening was a great opportunity to do some sightseeing while simultaneously showing solidarity with Ukraine. All in all 750 Volters from all over Europe travelled to Prague, making it the biggest GA in the still young history of Volt. The Czech Team and the Events Team of Volt Europe did a great job in organising a wonderful event that sadly ended way too fast.

ENGLISH

The Volt has visions of building a strong and sustainable EU through a Eurozone+ budget, a banking union and a full economic and monetary union under a European finance minister representing the EU.

We want to empower the European Central Bank to support jobs and growth and to prevent and resolve financial crises. In addition to curbing inflation, the European Central Bank's mandate must be extended to promoting employment, sustainable growth and crisis prevention and resolution.

We support international tax levels and we also propose a European tax agency to collect corporate taxes for companies operating in several European countries.
Tax avoidance by multinationals has undermined the funding of public services for decades and we want to prevent that in the future!

This morning, a historic earthquake shook Turkiye and Syria. So far, it is clear that thousands of buildings have collapsed, leaving untold damage and countless victims.  

Our thoughts are with the people of Turkiye and Syria. This severe tragedy calls for a broad international response. Echoing the EU's activation of the Civil Protection Mechanism, we call on all European governments to send aid, rescue workers and full support to the regions struck by the earthquake.

A disaster like this is a time to lay politics aside and focus on what is important: saving lives. We hope that regardless of the geopolitical challenges we all face, the spirit of human cooperation is placed first.

#VoltInThePress - Week 7 Summary:

Feb 13th - Netherlands - Trouw
The province of South Holland is in need of 18,500 structural shelters and housing for refugees and asylum seekers. The current leadership of the province has claimed that itâ€™ll be impossible for South Holland to fulfill its mandate. In this article, Juliet den Oudendammer (candidate MP for Volt in South Holland), argues that it is possible to realize these structural shelters, if only we show some political courage. It should be possible with smart housing policy, transforming current buildings into shelters, and as a last resort, pushing municipalities to realize more shelters. Housing is a fundamental right for everyone, including all (new) Dutch citizens.

The political party Volt is contesting this time the Provincial Council elections in eight provinces, including South Holland. Damian Boeselager, MEP from Volt, is currently negotiating a reform of European electoral law. His parliamentary position was last adopted in Strasbourg. According to him, there is still time to have the file adopted by member states before the next EU elections in 2024.

In last weekâ€™s summit in Brussels, EU leaders gathered to discuss the issue of migration. It was clear there that current leaders are putting fundamental human rights aside in favor of holding on to a clearly dysfunctional migration system that, besides being deeply unjust to Southern EU members, fails to protect human dignity and the value of life.

ğŸ§±They pledged substantial funds for surveillance and border security â€œstuffâ€, meaning that EU funds may indirectly end up in costly and useless projects such as fortifying the Turkish-Bulgarian border with fences.

Fact is: walls do not stop migration. Raising more obstacles to entry in the EU will only increase irregular migration along dangerous routes.

The EU must become a union of solidarity, enforcing a minimum threshold of asylum seekers per member state based on member state population, demographics and economic characteristics.

ğŸ‘·Swift inclusion into European societies with easy access to labour markets, education, and political participation is the next challenge.

If the EU really becomes â€œFortress Europeâ€™â€™, it will become a colder, increasingly isolated and culturally, politically, and economically poorer place. It would essentially be less equipped to deal with the multitude of challenges that have already started to manifest â€” let it be the climate crisis or the aging of our societies. Instead of being the source of endless political crises, migration â€” acknowledging its complex human dimensions â€” can be the source of societal enrichment.

The Ecological Greens, Greens, Greens-Solidarity, Pirates, Animal Party, Volt and the ecofeminist Quinni Circle are the seven parties that form the Green and Purple alliance to change the way politics is conducted in Greece. It is an alliance that aspires to bring into programmatic agreement different ideological approaches mainly on issues concerning the economy, labour, development and the concept of public interest. The Co-Presidents of Volt Greece are Olga Dourou and Nicolaos Fournarakis, Manos Avgerinos and Katerina Georgiou are the spokespersons.
Electra Rome Dochtsi, General Secretary of Volt Greece, said "Modern problems know no borders. The climate, energy and health crises, the war in Ukraine and the rapid rise of the far right have shown us that Europe needs change more than ever before. In Volt we believe that our country can improve if we improve the whole European Union.â€
Manos said in his interview: â€œIn about a month we're going to hold our first GA in Athens, hoping to become an attractive proposal and change the way politics is done in Greece. At the same time, we have also agreed to participate in the upcoming national elections with the Green and Purple coalition and generally the project is getting very interestingâ€.

Right after the preliminary results of the Berlin election came out (Volt got 0,9%), the parties Volt, Ã–DP and Piratenpartei released a press release jointly calling for the introduction of a substitute vote. The days between 2022 and the beginning of 2023 have been extremely hot all over Europe.
ğŸ“ˆEight countries broke national records for highest temperatures ever recorded in January.

ğŸŒ¡ï¸Poland reached 19 degrees Celsius. Temperature has exceeded 20 degrees in many European countries, such as in Italy, Belgium and Germany. Some areas of France reached 24 degrees, and Bilbao in Spain even reached 25 degrees!

ğŸ›¢ï¸These temperature records are not a surprise. Rather, they are a consequence of unhalted pollution by corporations and political failure to take serious action on this pollution.

ğŸŒ±Governments cannot continue to ignore what is the biggest threat to our future. The fight against climate change must become priority number 1! We need concrete measures as soon as possible to tackle climate change. We need to focus our forces to realise a real, rapid, and courageous ecological transition.

â„ï¸New Year's Eve in a t-shirt might sound nice, but think of the consequences. If no snow falls in the mountains in Winter, European rivers do not have enough water in Summer, increasing in severity the already common droughts we face in that time of year. Natural rhythms break down, and balance will be impossible to restore.

It is our responsibility to do what we can to stop this trend! Volt is committed across Europe to fight against climate change. Are you?

What is more important? Coal or the Climate? 

ğŸ›¢ï¸Since this week, preparations for the evacuation of LÃ¼tzerath, Germany are underway. The reason is the fact that the town sits on top of the largest brown coal (lignite) deposit in Europe. Germany is one of the last European countries to still use brown coal for energy, even though it is the most polluting and least efficient way to produce energy compared to alternatives like gas, wind, or nuclear. Huge amounts of CO2 are produced, and ecosystems are destroyed.

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ”¬LÃ¼tzerath has become a symbol for the coal phase-out 2030 and thus the compliance with the Paris Agreement. According to the German Institute for Economic Research, the coal under LÃ¼tzerath is only needed if Germany still relies on coal after 2030. But that would go hand in hand with exceeding 1.5 degrees of global warming, and show an unwillingness to transform to a green economy.

ğŸ˜¡The German and North-Rhein Westphalia state governments insist that LÃ¼tzerath must be mined: More lignite is to be used in 2023 & 2024. This is justified by the loss of Russian gas. However, studies have shown that the mining of further villages is not necessary, especially since because of the warm winter European gas reserves are much higher than anticipated. 

ğŸŒ±The switch should now instead be made to cleaner alternatives. The situation is symbolic but clear: mining lignite endangers the 1.5 degree limit and goes against the pledges by the German government and Europe as a whole. What happens with LÃ¼tzerath shows whether Germany is committed to the climate goals.

ğŸ’œThis issue affects all of Europe. Germany is one of the blocâ€™s core economies. If it continues to run on dirty coal, that means all of our economies continue to run on dirty coal. Volt takes a strong stand against the proliferation of fossil fuels, and we fight for increased attention to green alternatives for energy!

Earlier this month, MEPs, advocates and academics met to discuss policies for sustainable prosperity in Europe at the #BeyondGrowth conference. 

Much of the debate on future sustainability focuses on either degrowth, scaling down the scope of our economic activities, or on green growth, decoupling economic growth from environmental destruction. This debate is certainly justified but we should rather focus on the type and characteristics of growth we seek in society. 

And since the European Union represents around 16% of the World economy, the EU can and should lead the way to drive degrowth and green growth to the benefit of all economies, including todayâ€™s lower-income countries. Let's lay down the tracks now, so that all economies can grow and grow sustainably through:

ğŸ’° EU corporate taxation: The green transition needs to be financed. The EU needs to introduce EU-wide tax harmonisation, ultimately leading to European corporate taxes that can be centrally invested. This taxation should be progressive by turnover.
